DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent notice of motion No. 1, private members' business, given for Wednesday, 25 October 1989, relating to the air pilots dispute, being called on forthwith.

The Opposition introduces this motion because of the present disaster that is Australia's domestic aviation system. Despite the Government's pronouncements and those of the airlines that 62 per cent capacity is operating, clearly that is not true. We believe that there has been a fundamental breach of the two-airline agreement dated 28 May 1981 and the schedule to the airline agreement which approved it. The Airlines Agreement Act designates Ansett and Australian as the major operators of airline services in Australia for the transport of passengers. Section 6 (1) (a) of the schedule to the Act provides:

The parties shall take all reasonable action within their powers to ensure that the Commission and the Company are the only two operators which provide scheduled passenger air services over trunk routes within Australia.
However, the reason that we want to suspend standing orders relates to section 6 (1) (d) of that schedule, which states:

Without derogating from the objectives of sub-clause (1) (a), the parties acknowledge that nothing in this agreement shall preclude the Commonwealth, the Minister or the Secretary from permitting a passenger operator to develop specialised scheduled passenger air services over trunk routes of a nature which in the opinion of the Minister are not adequately provided for either by the Commission or the Company and for which after receiving a request in writing from the Minister neither the Commission nor the Company has, within a reasonable time, provided a service to the satisfaction of the Minister.

The agreement may not expressly cover the situation that one of the companies may decide to give up an airline business or to go into some other business, but it is obvious that the Act and the agreement mean that the companies are bound to provide adequate air services. Even if this is not the case, there is an express provision under section 6 (1) (d) which would enable the Minister to take action under the confines of that section. Our legal advice is that there is no escape route for a company, such as a force majeure or some other excuse, for not providing a service.

The Government has two options available to it under the agreement. The first is to cancel the agreement, if a breach of a fundamental obligation can be established. Clearly the failure to provide scheduled air services would satisfy that condition. The prospect of a 50 per cent service-and we do not agree that that level has been reached, even after two months of the dispute-appears to be within that obligation. Secondly, the Minister could act under the express powers of section 6 (1) (d), which seems to be clearly available in the circumstances. Our advice is that the application of this section is not limited in any way, such as a justifiable inability to provide the service.

We believe that a responsible government and Minister, acting in accordance with the national interest, and not being motivated by extraneous considerations, such as the present Government is, would take steps to enable other operators to enter the vacuum left by the two airlines in failing to take reasonable steps to ensure they can deliver the airline services which they have agreed to provide, and for which they have reaped great rewards from the Australian travelling public for many years.

The Opposition believes that it is a misuse of legal rights that the airlines are allowed to take their present course. Under the circumstances, the airlines would have a very great gall to take legal proceedings against the Commonwealth, to restrain it from taking whatever action was necessary to restore proper airline services for the nation. We believe that the national interest is very much at stake. Our principal export industry, tourism, also our biggest earner of foreign exchange, is in deep trouble. That industry is being destroyed in the major destinations of north Queensland, the Northern Territory, Western Australia and Tasmania. There are great difficulties in the other capital cities, and the flow-on effect to the service and primary industries is being very much felt. People are losing their businesses and all they own while this stupid dispute continues. Many small businesses will never recover. More than 15,000 people have already lost their jobs.

The airlines now both admit that they cannot get full services back before Easter of next year. While the Sydney to Melbourne sector is being serviced, most other routes have less than adequate services. Some have virtually no services at all. There have been no services to speak of from Adelaide to Perth, from Perth to north Queensland or from Adelaide to Brisbane during the dispute. Those people who have tried to book airline seats know the impossible situation that exists. Airline reservation systems take ages to answer the phone. There is no guarantee of seats and no guarantee of flights. There are delays in connections and there are no seats on demand. Tourists are just not travelling. The country is bleeding. The Government now has an opportunity to open up the skies to other carriers that may be able to provide scheduled services in their own right. It is clear that adequate services are just not being provided.

Random checks on what is normally operating establish the inadequacies of the present situation. Last Tuesday, 17 October, the domestic airlines provided two services from Perth to the eastern States. Normally there are 11 services. In terms of seats available, that represented 20.74 per cent of capacity. Out of Cairns on recent weekends, there was about 23 per cent seat capacity. Normally there are 17 flights per day. Now, there is a likelihood at best of four or five flights using military and civilian aircraft-some in the very early hours of the morning.

As an example I cite last Monday's domestic services from Melbourne. On the Melbourne to Adelaide run there was 31 per cent seat capacity. The seat capacity from Melbourne to Hobart was 46 per cent. From Melbourne to Launceston it was 11.5 per cent. The seat capacity from Melbourne to Brisbane was 12.5 per cent, and from Melbourne to Canberra it was 32 per cent. Whilst Sydney and Melbourne are retaining some services, how many flights have run on the crucial tourist routes such as from Perth to Alice Springs and Cairns, from Cairns to Darwin and from Adelaide to Perth? The answer is nil. There is no resemblance between the timetables and what flies.

Any similarity between the forward schedules that used to be published in newspapers and what actually flies is purely coincidental. There are constant flight delays and nobody would accept that any type of reasonable service currently exists. We have been told constantly that airlines are carrying 62 per cent seat capacity. Australian Airlines is even saying that it will have 80 per cent seat capacity next month. Is that figure genuine? The Opposition believes that the airlines have failed to meet their obligations for providing services. Therefore, the Government should be responsive under the Act and should allow new players into the game. They may not all be full airlines, but there are carriers that could provide some scheduled services. I believe also that there are prospective players who can accelerate their efforts to enter the Australian airline business.

The figures that I have cited do not include the international carriers. There is a reason for this. On two occasions I have been told by airline reservations staff that the airlines are `not selling those seats now as we have enough of our own'. That has been confirmed to me by two international airlines. As part of opening up the system, the Opposition believes that the Government should allow full interlining to continue in order to ease the burden and should allow travel agents and the public direct access to those international carriers, because they can provide more seating capacity.

Termination of the agreement would allow some overseas charter operators to come to Australia in their own right and to provide scheduled services until such time as the Australian carriers are back to full operation and new Australian operators are also in service. Of course, safety would be maintained at all times. The cost of the pilots dispute is enormous. The cost to tourism and business is outrageous. The personal cost to Australian families is being felt in many ways, especially in times of personal tragedy. Australia does not have adequate air services. The Opposition believes that, in the national interest, the Government should now cancel the two-airline agreement and allow more operators into our air routes. The Government has the power to do that. It must act now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Let me state very bluntly what we are putting in this motion. We are saying to the two airlines, Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, that if they cannot deliver the goods they should close up shop and let someone else in who can deliver the goods. This is exactly what the Government should be saying to the two airlines after 11 weeks of this protracted dispute. It should be saying clearly to the two airlines, `We gave you a closed shop but only so long as you provided regular air services. You are not doing that now; so nick off and give someone else a go'.

SPEECH.PARA: All of this becomes very clear from a reading of the two airlines agreement. It all follows logically from two clauses of the agreement. The first point is that under the agreement only the two major airlines are allowed to operate domestic passenger services over trunk routes throughout Australia. That is made very clear in clause 6 (1) (a) of the agreement, which I paraphrase as follows: the parties shall take all reasonable action within their powers to ensure that Australian Airlines and Ansett are the only two operators which provide scheduled domestic passenger air services over trunk routes within Australia. That clause means that Australian Airlines and Ansett, while they provide services and only while they provide services, are in and all other operators are locked out.

The second point which is also very clear from the agreement is that if Australian Airlines and Ansett do not operate services over a trunk route, the Government can allow another operator in. That appears very clearly in clause 6 (1) (d), which the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) has already read out. These two things are exactly what we would expect the agreement to provide. But what we have now is a situation where on any test Australian and Ansett are not providing services over the trunk routes of Australia. Even if we accept their own case, they are not providing the full services-the services they contracted to provide; the services they promised to provide. Of course the honourable member for Fadden has shown that they are providing even fewer services than they claim.

Even if the two airlines are right-let us assume for a moment that they are-they are not providing the services they committed themselves to provide and therefore are in breach of the two airlines agreement. That breach is a fundamental breach, a substantial breach and a breach which is sustained and prolonged. As my colleague has already pointed out, there is no clause in the agreement for what is known as force majeure; there is no excuse for giving the two airlines a let-out, if that is what they want to rely on, and saying they are not at fault for the dispute, its prolonged nature and the resulting breach of agreement. In any case, the airlines are clearly in deliberate breach of the agreement because their refusal to negotiate with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots has obviously prolonged the breach.

All of this being so, the Government has two courses open to it. The first course is to give a notice under clause 6 (1) (d) and let other operators in. In other words, the Government can say to the two airlines, `We gave you this closed shop. You have not delivered; so we give you notice that the whole agreement is coming to an end and we are letting other operators in'. Alternatively-and this is what the Government should do-it can rescind the agreement. It should do exactly that, for the two airlines have given away their right to have the exclusive right to operate domestic trunk services. If the Government has an ounce of responsibility left it will do this; it will take the first decent step it has taken during this whole dispute and rescind the two airlines agreement, thus taking a positive step towards restoring full air services for the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will reject this motion on several grounds. The first and most important ground is that it is yet another example of the axis which has been drawn by the Opposition front bench with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots in order to deprive Australian citizens of their services. The second reason we will reject it is for the cant and hypocrisy that it represents. Nothing could be more hypocritical in this place than to see the previous speaker, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), stand up at this box as a member of the Government that brought in the two airlines agreement in its latest form over the opposition of all of us who were on the Opposition front bench at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition set in train this lock-in. If we are looking for the first causes of the current airline dispute, they go back to the two airlines agreement, which permitted the growth of the sort of featherbedding that the domestic airlines are trying to deal with in the totally unreasonable demands of the Pilots Federation. If the Opposition is looking for first causes, it should go back beyond the decision by the pilots earlier this year to enter into a confrontation with the airlines. The pilots had the political power and the industrial muscle to be able to do that because of the previous Government's arrangements. Those arrangements were set in place when this Opposition was in government. We are now struggling with the industrial consequences of that. Indeed, the airlines are struggling with the industrial consequences of that.

Opposition members should not get up here with their easy, facile, bush lawyers' talk about doing this or that with the two airlines agreement. I had the responsibility of administering the two airlines agreement for a couple of years, during which time I was trying to press some of its edges. Let me tell the House that it is not quite the easy, open-ended thing the Opposition is talking about, particularly when the trunk routes are being flown by the airlines, as they are. That is hypocritical nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, you are a lawyer?

—I am not a lawyer and neither is the honourable member. The difference between the honourable member and me is that I have had some experience in administering the Act, which he has not. He will never administer an Act of the Commonwealth. He has not had the experience in the past and he will not have it in the future. That is the end of that matter. He knows nothing about it, as he knows nothing about the subjects for which he has found himself responsible from time to time as an Opposition frontbencher. This is part of the axis which had developed between the Opposition and the Federation of Air Pilots to disrupt services to the people of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Since this dispute began, the Opposition has sought to undermine every effort by the Government to provide services to the travelling public. The bleeding hearts opposite come in here and tell us that they are concerned about what is happening to the flying public of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us whether you have addressed the question seriously.
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas!

—These same bleeding hearts had the Opposition's defence spokesman, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), put out a press release a week or so ago in which he said that it was time the Government took the Royal Australian Air Force off the routes, that it was time the Government pulled the RAAF out of providing services to the public. Opposition members are in here today telling us that they want the public served. Yet their spokesman on defence is putting out press releases saying that the Opposition does not want the public served. What sort of cant and hypocrisy is that? The Opposition said originally that it supported the RAAF coming in, but now it does not support the RAAF coming in. Who is the RAAF supporting? It is flying people out of Cairns. It is flying people out of Western Australia. It is flying people out of the Northern Territory. It is covering those routes that the Opposition has been talking about, but now it opposes the RAAF covering those routes. That is the first thing that might well be said about the cant and hypocrisy that underlines this motion and the reason we will not support it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has gone down the road of supporting the Federation of Air Pilots on its bogus claims on safety. It ill becomes the Opposition spokesman to get up and prate about that. As was revealed in the Senate Estimates Committee, when this matter was considered in some considerable detail, the Opposition's premature support for those bogus safety claims was thoroughly exposed. But its support did not come from a concern about safety; it came from a concern to back the Federation of Air Pilots in this issue.

The Opposition takes that matter a point further. Let us just look a little more deeply at the question of safety and at the lies and nonsense being told by the Federation of Air Pilots on that issue and many other issues. On the one hand, the Federation, which the Opposition backs, claims that it supports safety; on the other hand, it is prepared to harass pilots in briefing rooms and as they enter air terminals to fly the aircraft. What hypocrisy by the Federation and by the Opposition.

The question then is: What services are being provided by the airlines? The airlines are getting their aircraft into the air, which is a matter the Opposition hates, opposes and does not want, and they are also now bringing in leased aircraft. Australian Airlines announced the other day that four charter aircraft are already being used. It has taken a lease on five more late series 737-300s, two later series 757s and a 727. The airlines are bringing capacity into this country as they confront the tough and difficult situation of trying to get what is now effectively a restructuring of their airlines and to get people back to work.

I would have thought that this was the sort of thing the Opposition was most interested in with regard to its industrial policy. When employers decided that they will take on their employees in major restructuring-albeit in this situation an unprovoked restructuring, because the airlines had no intention of confronting the situation they now confront-one would have thought there would be a bit of guts, a bit of backbone, a bit of backing from the Opposition, but there has not been. What we see in the Opposition is people incapable of holding a policy line in their heads and understanding the significance of it. We see people totally incapable of holding a policy line in their heads and sticking to it. The Opposition has found itself in a situation where common sense would have dictated solid backing for the Government and the airlines in this regard and some sort of statement on the part of the Opposition that this is the way it intends going about doing it. The moment something like this comes up, albeit a creation in the first instance of its own legislation, off the Opposition goes, running for the doctor.

Not only does the Opposition do that, but also it goes through the process of supporting the lies and calumnies told by the executive members of the Federation in order to keep their troops in line. It is quite obvious to the Opposition-and this is one of the reasons that we see these motions coming up now-that the executive of the Federation of Air Pilots is finding it harder and harder to hold its members in line. They are obliged to go to more and more extreme tactics to hold their members in line. The Federation of Air Pilots says, `It is a problem, we cannot hold our members in line. Who do we go to to help us in our hour of need as we can no longer hold our airline pilots in line? We go to the good old Federal Opposition'. They are going around at their meetings saying, `Do not worry, wait until the next election. We will work very hard to elect the Opposition, the people with whom we have formed an axis, because they are going to direct Australian Airlines to pick up all the old pilots. So let us get the Opposition into office as quickly as possible'. The Opposition is a reliable supporter of the Federation executive against the interests of the travelling public, the airlines and the pilots themselves.

This is yet another example of the Opposition's policy. It is not motivated by any genuine concern for the travelling public. The whole crisis is a product of its own administration of aviation policy. It is the act of the Opposition that is being talked about in here. We as a House ought not to support this sort of hypocrisy. We ought to have a sense of dignity about ourselves.

DEBATE.TITLE: JUDICIAL AND STATUTORY OFFICERS REMUNERATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Judicial and Statutory Officers Remuneration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which proposes some increases in the salaries of Federal judges and others in judicial and quasi-judicial situations in the Federal structure. We support the Bill because Federal judges' salaries have been falling behind and there is a case for increasing them. As the second reading speech makes plain, the matter has been before the Remuneration Tribunal, which proposed very large increases indeed-increases so large that the Government felt that the community would not support increases of that size in judicial salaries.
—Eighty per cent.

—Indeed, as my colleague reminds me, the proposed increases were about 80 per cent, which was very much on the high side. For that reason, the matter went back to the Remuneration Tribunal, which did the job again and came back with other recommendations. It is those recommendations in substance, with some amendments, I think, which are incorporated in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the legislation, because the salaries of Federal judges have been falling behind and there is a case for having them increased. In the past several reasons have been advanced as to why judges should, to put it bluntly, have reasonably high salaries. Although it is important not to exaggerate it, the fact is that, without judges receiving reasonable salaries, governments would not be able to attract the best people to the Bench. I emphasise that it is important not to exaggerate that argument, because there are other reasons why judicial office is attractive to practising lawyers. There are, of course, reasons other than money which deter successful practitioners in the law from taking judicial positions that are offered to them. Nevertheless, putting that all in balance and all in context and giving reasonable weight to it, one is still left with the conclusion that, without reasonable salaries being paid to judges, governments will not be able to attract the best people to the Bench.

Specifically, when we come to the Federal sphere, we find that there have been two recent resignations of Federal Court judges-Mr Justice Fitzgerald, as he then was, and Mr Justice Jackson. One would not, of course, seek to inquire into the reasons for their early retirements. One really would have to reach the conclusion that the comparatively low salaries and the absence of any increase in those salaries when judges expected them to be increased probably contributed to their early retirement. That, I think, is unfortunate, because they were both regarded as extremely good judges and, of course, both are regarded as extremely highly qualified and competent practitioners.

The second point which I think illustrates this is the fact that it is now common knowledge-at least at the Victorian Bar, being the branch of the profession with which I am most familiar-that many leading practitioners will not in fact accept appointment to the Bench; many good, competent people simply will not now accept appointment and do not regard a judicial position as being part of their expected or desired career path. Once again, it must be emphasised that this is not solely because of money; it is not solely because of the salaries. Nevertheless, again putting it into some balance and some context, one is, I believe, left with the conclusion that the level of current salaries, both Federal and State, is one of the reasons why many leading practitioners do not regard judicial office as a position to which they aspire. For those reasons, the thrust of the Bill must be supported.

We believe there is a case for increasing Federal judicial and quasi-judicial salaries and allowances. No doubt, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have noticed that, in terms of allowances, overnight allowances and such like, judges seem to do much better than members of parliament. I do not know why this is so. It has always been a mystery to me. Perhaps it is expected that when judges are on circuit, they will stay in posher establishments than we are expected to stay in. Perhaps they eat more, or perhaps their food is more expensive. I do not know what the reason is. But for whatever the reason, they in fact receive quite considerable allowances which are higher than ours. I hope that one day I will find the reason for that. For years I have been searching in vain, but I live in hope.

The other point that should be made is that Family Court judges are now to be paid the same as Federal Court judges. One of the reasons advanced in support of this is that the jurisdiction of Family Court judges has been increased as they have taken up part of the jurisdiction which was previously confined to Federal Court judges. In other words, to put it bluntly, Family Court judges now do some of the work of Federal Court judges and therefore it is accepted that they deserve parity in their pay. I think the best thing to do about that is to accept it and accept the justification for it, because life as a Family Court judge is not a bed of roses. I can assure honourable members that life as a Family Court judge is a hard one. The problems which Family Court judges face are probably more trying and testing in a personal sense than the problems and difficulties faced by judges of other courts. Parity of salary, which we are now to see, is some recognition of the burdens of office which are carried by Family Court judges.

There is only one other matter I want to refer to, although there are Government amendments to the Bill which it may be necessary to say something about at a later stage. I can now inform the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) that, having seen those amendments, we will be supporting them. I can understand the reasons that will be advanced for them. Leaving that aside, the other matter to which I wish to refer is this: high judicial salaries should have, one can reasonably hope, one result, among others-that is, that judges act as judges and confine themselves to judicial office; that they keep out of politics and government. I do not think that that is entirely judges' fault by any means, but in recent years there have been some very disturbing trends in some aspects of the judicial culture in Australia and it is related to this point.

The most serious of these, I believe, is the confusion of the judicial function which has been generated by having judges preside over royal commissions and sitting on tribunals and other bodies of an essentially political or governmental nature. That practice has grown over recent years. It is a bad practice and it should be stopped. The Supreme Court of the State of Victoria does not engage in that practice. Its judges will not sit on royal commissions, and should not sit on royal commissions. The last one who sat on a royal commission was a judge who presided over the Royal Commission into Communism-not the Petrov royal commission but the earlier one into communism. The very mention of the fact that that was the subject of the royal commission would, I think, convince you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is an undesirable situation in which to put a judge, because essentially he must come to conclusions, if he is to carry out his terms of reference and comply with them, about people's political activities, government and the functions of government, which are the proper province of elected governments and not the proper province of judges who are not elected but whose function is to resolve disputes between citizens impartially.

It has been very disturbing for me to see over the years the growing practice of governments asking judges to do their dirty work for them, because in substance that is what it is on many occasions. Governments ask judges to do this for them to give an air of respectability to their activities which would otherwise not be there. In other words, the commission or the government activity, even if it is a complete set-up from beginning to end, looks much more respectable when a judge presides over it than it would otherwise. The result-and this is the point of the whole thing-is that quite often it leads to an express or implied clash between governments and judges when judges take, as they are often forced to do, essentially political decisions. Therefore, the standing of the judiciary is diminished.

Probably the best illustration of that which is available to me at the moment is a charming report in the Melbourne Age of 25 September 1989 under the heading `Judge and minister clash over human rights record'. It is a report of some activities that took place at a Human Rights Congress in Melbourne at which Mr Justice Einfeld, the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, who is of course a judge of the Federal Court, made some contributions. He relieved himself of the observation that Australia's treatment of Aborigines had reached the proportions of genocide, if you please. Whether that is right or wrong, that is essentially a political judgment. It is not a judicial function to reach conclusions of that sort. He went on to say that the attitudes of many white Australians to the bulk of black Australians were `to put it simply, at least elitist if not racist'. Those are very strong words indeed.

The Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, said, in my view quite rightly, that those views expressed by Mr Justice Einfeld-a judge of the Federal Court of Australia, as well as being the President of this outfit-were distorted. I do not think it is appropriate, and it does not contribute much to the debate, for me or anyone else to go into some competition to assess who was right and who was wrong. I know where I would put my money, but the point about it is not so much that; the point is that we have a clash. As the headline says, `Judge and minister clash over human rights record'. Mr Justice Einfeld is being held out on this occasion not as President of the Human Rights Commission but as a judge.

It is unhealthy for our governmental system, the Federal Court and the judiciary in general to have that sort of slanging match going on between a judge and a Minister. It is doubly bad, of course, because the judge, having been appointed to this position, is virtually obliged to come down from the bench and get into hand to hand combat on these essentially political and judgmental matters which are the province of the Human Rights Commission and which are not the province of courts, including the court of which he is a member. That is a healthy illustration of this very unfortunate trend.

For instance-I make no criticism at all of any of the individuals involved, and I emphasise that-when we have Mr Justice Helsham involved in the Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, thereafter one cannot but reflect on the fact that he was the judge who held that particular opinion or view about a contentious matter of the environment in this country, whether he is right or wrong.

Mr Justice Stewart, who is still described as Mr Justice Stewart-hot from the National Crime Authority, now into the Resource Assessment Commission-presumably will be expressing views about the development of resources in this country, where there will be enormous controversy, debate and differences of opinion. I ask whether it is healthy for a judge to be involved in that sort of activity. I give the answer: no, it is not. It leads, in some extreme cases, to some very silly things being said. For instance, when it was announced the other day that Mr Justice Lee was to preside over the royal commission concerning a former police officer, Mr Blackburn, the ABC News said that a `prosecuting judge', Mr Justice Lee, was to preside over these proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The judge would not be happy with that.

—I am sure that he would be unhappy with that description. One could go on all day about these things, but once we depart from sound basic principles, we get into trouble, in this area as in most other areas. Of course, governments do achieve their objectives by having judges preside over royal commissions, especially when it is the government itself which is in trouble, because if the government is cleared-and it may well be cleared because it is right on the facts and the merits-it can always say, when it is challenged, `Yes, but this conclusion was reached by a real live judge, so it must be right.' It might be right according to the judge, but it may also be wrong politically and a decision that is rejected by the people when they have a chance to vote on it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I have made the point, without going on at length about it, but I come back to the basic point that judicial salaries should be high, in keeping with the sorts of principles we apply to all wage fixing these days-and, of course, there is contention about that. We are left with the conclusion that judicial salaries should be high. One of the consequences of that should be that judges remain as judges and that governments allow them to remain as judges and allow them to perform their proper judicial function. I take an example which might make the point clearer. No-one, to my knowledge, has ever cast the slightest aspersion over the Supreme Court of Victoria or its judges. One reason for that is that the court has always kept itself at arm's length from governments, royal commissions, tribunals, or any ramshackle outfits invented by governments to get themselves off the hook, to have an inquiry into things, to give an air of independence and objectivity about things. The Supreme Court of Victoria has never touched that, certainly not since 1949, and that is one reason why that court has never been the subject of any besmirchment or suggestion of impropriety in any shape or form, and I think that is a good thing. Unfortunately, when we have the practice of individual judges of the courts taking up quasi-political and quasi-government positions, the court from which the judge comes suffers because there is a reflection on the court, no matter what the judge does. I believe that the judiciary as a whole suffers.

The Opposition supports the Bill. We believe that there is a case for increasing salaries and allowances. Judges have been very concerned about their salaries; some of them have even approached members of parliament in airport lounges and such, saying, `It really is outrageous that our salaries are not increased.'. After I agree with them, I remind them that the salaries, before they were increased, were double our salaries. I remind them of that before they go off on their overnight stay on a higher allowance than we receive. Nevertheless, we come here voluntarily, knowing what the salary is, and we have to bear that. Judges cannot speak for themselves in public debate, and it must be said on their behalf that judicial salaries have, in the Federal sphere, fallen behind those in the State spheres, and fallen behind those that could reasonably be expected. I trust that the judges will be satisfied with this, at least for the time being, and that those receiving the salary increases will be happy that the Parliament has acknowledged that there is a case for bringing them up to the State levels and increasing those salaries. We support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) for yielding to me for these brief minutes. I refer to the comments of the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), the esteemed shadow Attorney-General and Queen's Counsel, and point out to him that people can and do classify judges philosophically. When appointments are made to the High Court of Australia, people often make assessments that the new appointee is a centralist or federalist at heart. Whilst I believe that the members of the High Court make their judgments with integrity and honesty, they cannot shake off their basic direction of thinking; their thinking train is there. Governments often carefully select appointees to the High Court because they know that a certain individual thinks in a certain way, or they reject individuals on the same ground.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the case that the shadow Attorney-General made in relation to judges taking roles in royal commissions and the like, one of the great problems of governments is that people have little trust in governments of any political persuasion. I say to the honourable member for Menzies: whether it be the Liberal Party in power or the Labor Party in power, there is still a basic distrust of governments. I recognise the desirability of judges keeping away from controversy. However, there will be occasions when a person who is seen to have no particular axe to grind one way or the other can bring to a judgment not only respectability but also a degree of impartiality.

Indeed, the Liberal Party when in government appointed judges. I remember very clearly the royal commission that was held in 1978, during which I spent three or four days appearing under the torchlight of Mr Tom Hughes, QC, and others. Being questioned in that way was an experience I would not recommend to anybody as a pastime.

The honourable member for Menzies is a lawyer, and I can well understand some of those judges sidling up to him in airports and other places. However, the point he did not make during his speech was that the Remuneration Tribunal recommended an 80 per cent increase in judges' salaries and, on review, that has now settled down to a level of 30 per cent. It must be to the chagrin of the pilots that this Parliament today is unanimously supporting a 30 per cent increase in salary for judges when at the same time the Government is saying no to the pilots. I do not intend to become political on this issue. The point is that, in comparison with the income of the better lawyers and barristers, judges' salaries are low.

Out there in the community lawyers and barristers with ability are saying, `Why would I want to become a judge for 100 grand or 120 grand a year when out here in the community I can earn, say, a quarter of a million dollars, half a million dollars or even more a year?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why else would we do it?

—If ever a sacrifice were made, it was made by the honourable member for Menzies, Neil Brown, QC, and the honourable member for North Sydney, John Spender, QC, who sit in this House on 55 grand a year. As the honourable member for Menzies said, he made that choice, as indeed do barristers or solicitors who accept the invitation to become judges.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem confronting society today is that fewer and fewer people of great ability are willing to go onto the Bench. That situation can be corrected by increasing the salary levels of judges to put their salary levels closer to the level of income of successful lawyers and barristers. However, that approach does not come to grips with the problem that confronts the ordinary man. Unless one is a pensioner who is entitled to legal aid, unless one is a Christopher Skase of a week ago, a Bond of a couple of months ago, or a person who can charge legal costs up to a successful company, the price of justice today is beyond the ordinary person. It is beyond middle Australia. The middle Australian either has to be driven by a belief that he is prepared to lose everything in the pursuit of what he sees as justice or he has to walk away from the judicial system. It is a continuing crime that that is the way in which the pursuit of justice has been allowed not only to continue but also to accelerate over the years. That is why Queen's Counsel and barristers are earning huge six-figure sums and why, in comparison, the salaries of their brother judges are infinitely less than they could be earning outside.

Because I believe that this time next year the shadow Minister will be the Attorney-General, I make a plea to him to recognise that one of the greatest challenges facing governments today is to work to put justice back within the financial reach of the average Mr and Mrs Australia. At present, people who are either poor or rich can afford justice but it is outside the reach of the middle Australian.

I make those observations only because this Bill is before the House. I repeat that the level of salary increase averages around 30 per cent, which is in line with the figure for another group at the moment. In reply to the shadow Minister's comment about why judges need additional allowances to those paid to politicians, I suggest that it is probably another way of getting around the problem that was alluded to. Giving them a little more on the side may make up some of the difference that exists between the remuneration of judges and that of their brothers at the Bar or even in private practice as solicitors in some instances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I should correct some of the figures that were mentioned by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron). He spoke about a 30 per cent salary increase for judges and linked that with the pilots' claim. If one looks at the figures one notes that, for instance, prior to this legislation, the Chief Justice of the High Court was receiving $134,000. His salary will rise to $160,000. On my quick calculations, that is more like 17 per cent, not 30 per cent. The present salary for judges of the Federal Court is $103,000, which will rise to $124,000, an increase of about 19 per cent. I believe that the honourable member for Moreton will find that his claim of a 30 per cent increase is not correct. In fact, we are talking about increases of between 17 per cent and 20 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) said, the Remuneration Tribunal originally recommended increases of 80 per cent, which certainly was not acceptable to this Government. The Government has a policy of wages restraint. It has current wage fixing guidelines within which it requires people to work. As members of parliament we have been bound to work within those guidelines. I know what that is like because, back in 1984, as a State member of parliament I was earning approximately $69,000 a year. Admittedly, I was the Leader of the Opposition. However, when I became a member of this House I was earning something like $43,000 a year. I believe that people have a misunderstanding about our salaries, and it is important to correct that situation.

I take the point made by both speakers from the Opposition that there has been a need to sort out the remuneration for judges at the Federal level. A comparison of judges throughout the nation reveals that the Supreme Court judges of the various States have been giving the lead in high salaries. Regrettably, Queensland has certainly led the march. Whilst the remuneration for judges at the Federal level is now being lifted, I note that Queensland has again leapt ahead. To take up the point made by the honourable member for Menzies, if we are going to keep Federal judges in line with their State counterparts, we are going to have to raise their salaries again.

There is an important point here, namely, that we must attract the best legal minds to the Bench. I know that claims are made that being a judge has a particular status, that it has advantages outside dollars. However, we still need to ensure, when judges are appointed to the Federal Court, the Family Court, indeed, to any other court, that the best legal minds are appointed. When one considers the salaries that top silks earn at the Bar, one finds that they are earning in excess of $250,000 per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the rest.

—I take the honourable member's point. I shall mention some of the other figures I have pulled out. Some of the senior partners in major legal firms in Sydney and Melbourne are earning $400,000 a year. Look at the senior executives of some firms. I know Mr Elliott has just increased his wages to $1.5m, but many of his middle management people are earning $200,000 and $300,000. Yet we are saying to the Chief Justice of this nation that he shall earn only $160,000. So something is wrong in those links and comparisons. Obviously we do not want remuneration to be a deterrent to judges, so this Bill is warranted. No-one likes to see major increases outside of what the ordinary people are getting, but it is certainly warranted here.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up another point made by the honourable member for Menzies. He questioned whether it was healthy for judges to be involved in social and community issues. I believe that is what he was saying. I take his point, bearing in mind the examples he gave, but I suggest that there are advantages in judges speaking out on issues. I recently came across a case that was brought to court by the Trade Practices Commission involving Gary Scott Stevenson. He was fined $68,000 for business practices that contravened the Trade Practices Act. He was one of those fellows involved in the blowing industry. For those who do not understand that, it involves advertising agencies, publishers and others sorting out deals on the telephone. They `blow' the person. They will ring up and make out that some firm has taken an advertisement. They will not ask whether the firm still wants the advertisement but instead use the smart tactic of reading through the advertisement they have, often taken out of the yellow pages. They will ask the young lass or whoever has answered the phone whether they have the correct spelling of the firm's name, whether they have the correct phone numbers and so on. They then proceed to print a magazine with that advertisement on it, sending the bill to that firm for an advertisement they have never authorised.

Gary Scott Stevenson has been involved in these types of practices. He was fined $68,000, but I doubt whether a quarter of a quarter of a quarter of one per cent of people in this country knew about it. Had the judge at the time made more of the fact that this fellow has rorted the system, that he was out there ripping off hundreds of small business people and had gathered himself tens of thousands of dollars in profit because of the unscrupulous practices that he was involved in, maybe we would not have these two publications I will refer to on the market today. I refer to the publications Design and Focus. Whilst I take the point of the honourable member for Menzies that there can be a question mark over statements made by judges when it comes to human rights and environmental issues because of the enormous status and weight given to their comments, I personally believe there is value in judges speaking out firmly on some of the matters that come before them. This fellow Stevenson ought to have been paraded in the media as the rogue that he is in the hope that no more business people would get caught.

Let me refer to some of the examples that I have here. These publications are produced by a group called Hilton Publications, sometimes flying under the name Esquire Publications. The address of Hilton Publications is 695 Burke Road, Camberwell, Victoria; the address of Esquire Publications is Forest Hill, Victoria. I note that the honourable member for Menzies is smiling. I hope that it is not in his electorate. Eight of these operations are owned by a fellow called Alex McKenzie. One of these magazines is called Focus, and it has on it that it is a journal of trade and industry. The one I have is volume 8, No. 2, of March 1989. The other one is Design, and it is said to be a journal of trade and commerce. The one I have is volume 8, No. 2, April 1989. These magazines charge $205-in one case $206, although that might have been a computer error-for small advertisements. They get eight advertisements to the A4 page. I have measured them; they are 8.5 centimetres by 6 centimetres. The publications contain 36 pages. But they are phoney magazines. For instance, whilst it is claimed that Focus is widely distributed among industry and commerce, departments and trade unions, when I rang Alex McKenzie he admitted that he produced only 1,000 to 1,500 copies. It is nothing more than a moneymaking rip-off. They are full of advertisements. There is page after page of advertisements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member for Capricornia that we are discussing the Judicial and Statutory Officers Remuneration Legislation Amendment Bill and, whilst what he is saying is related to the issue before the House, I think we are getting a little too far away from the Bill. The honourable member might bear those comments in mind.

—I seek your forbearance on this, Mr Deputy Speaker. The point made by the honourable member for Menzies was a valuable one. It is a valid point that judges have to be extremely careful, but I am taking a countering position in this debate on the measure before the House because I believe, as I shall prove, there are times when judges ought to speak out. To demonstrate that to the House I need to present these examples. So, with your concurrence, I shall just proceed a little longer to demonstrate the problems with magazines such as Focus and Design. As I said, these are supposed to be journals of trade and commerce. In an issue I have here, nine of the last 11 pages are advertisements.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us look at the articles to demonstrate why judges need to expose these operations. One article-remember that this is a trade and commerce magazine-is called `The Arrival of the First Fleet in the Great Southland'. What interest that would have to the leaders of trade and commerce I do not know. Another article is labelled `Speech Notes for National Farmers Federation President Mr Ian McLachlan addressing the Annual Conference of the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association-2nd May 1987'. But the article appeared in volume 8, No. 2, of April 1989. An article in Focus, which is a magazine for trade and industry, covers guidelines for the Australian driver new to driving in an unnamed Middle East country. Another one has no title and no author. Another is headed `Meteorological Co-operation in Europe'. The one that really got my attention is the final story in Design. It is headed `The Bushranging Days'. I would suggest that that is a most fitting story to appear in what has to be the best bushranging magazine that I have come across in a long time.

My point is that there is a need for these types of people to be exposed, and when we have a fellow like Gary Scott Stevenson coming before a judge and being fined $68,000 it is my personal opinion that whilst it can be unhealthy, as the honourable member for Menzies says, to get too involved in social and community issues there is a time and a place for judges to speak out. I see the need for judges to get tough not only in terms of penalties and fines that they impose but also in issuing public warnings. Hundreds of small business people right across this nation are getting caught up with these rogues, these bogus publishers, and the Trade Practices Commission can do little about it. As you would be aware, sir, if I were to say to anyone, `Here is a biro and I want $100,000 for it' and some person wanted to give me that, that is legal. If I said it had been used by the Duke of Edinburgh, that is a different matter. I would have misrepresented. These fellows simply produce magazines saying that they are journals of trade and commerce. There is little we can do about it unless we teach the community to beware. I believe there is a role for the judges to ensure that these types of people are exposed. They have a special role. Whilst it may be on an edge as to how far judges should go in what they say, I believe they ought to make comment, they ought to give public warnings, and in that way they will expose the rogues and the public will be warned. I believe that the community would be a far better place.

On the specific measures of the Bill, I believe that judges earn the money that we pay them. There is a need for Federal judges, who represent this nation in the courts, to be paid reasonable remuneration. It is an awkward situation for us to find that our Chief Justice, for instance, could be paid less than a Supreme Court judge in one of the States or a judge of the Federal Court. We will need to constantly monitor this position. Whilst maintaining the Government's wage restraints, we must ensure that low remuneration is not a deterrent to the best legal minds in this country going to the Bench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no disagreement about the Judicial and Statutory Officers Remuneration Legislation Amendment Bill. Much has been said on the Bill with which I agree, so I shall confine myself to a few points. One of the points I wish to make is one that has not been made, and that is that the question of judges' salaries has been treated by this Government as a political football. Those words are not mine; they are the words of the Chief Justice, Sir Anthony Mason, used in an address on the state of the Australian judicature in August this year. In his address he pointed out the problems that the erosion of salaries had brought to judicial recruitment. He referred to the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal in 1988 to the effect that there should be an 80 per cent increase in judges' salaries, and to the Government's decision on that. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: After the Tribunal made its initial recommendation last November, judicial salary increases became a political football. The media carried reports of negotiation between the Government and the A.C.T.U.-
the Australian Council of Trade Unions!-

What has happened in relation to the handling of judicial salaries may have encouraged others; it did nothing to encourage the judges. The unhappy story is not calculated to inspire the Australian Judiciary with confidence in the present procedures for determining judicial remuneration.

That is what Sir Anthony Mason said. I remind the House that about a year or so later after the first determination we are now dealing with something which should have been dealt with urgently because the erosion in judges' salaries has directly affected the capacity to recruit to the Bench and the capacity to keep judges on the Bench. That is a point that is made also by Sir Ninian Stephen, himself a former justice of the High Court of Australia. Earlier this year when he spoke of the evil of the erosion of judicial salaries he said:

The evil of this erosion of judicial salaries will continue as a threat to judicial independence so long as sporadic and partial correction of the process of erosion is left to depend upon the very arms of government of which the judiciary should be independent-it being dependent upon the executive for effective initiation and upon the legislature for implementation.

What have we had here? We had the Remuneration Tribunal making a recommendation. That was not accepted by the Executive of this Government. Why was it not accepted? It was not accepted because it did not fit in with the accord and with the ACTU. We have the grotesque situation of the matter then getting into the hands of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) as though what we had with the original determination by the Remuneration Tribunal was an ambit claim made by the airline pilots. In fact, it was a determination which pointed out that there had been a substantial erosion of judges' salaries over the years and that there were good reasons for increasing those salaries. Amongst other things it pointed to the greater complexity of work in courts these days-something that the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) would know something about, as do I.

We have a Bill a year later to increase the salaries to the levels that have been referred to. In the meantime it is paradoxical to note that the New South Wales Government recruited to the position of Independent Commissioner Against Corruption a lawyer who is to be paid far more than the Chief Justice of this country. He is to be paid $175,000. It is no wonder that it is difficult to recruit at all levels, State and Federal, to the judiciary. If we speak to people whose job it is to recruit we will know just how hard it is. I do not think that the levels should be back to the levels they were at the time the High Court was first formed. In those days a justice of the High Court got #3,000, which was somewhere around 80 times average weekly earnings, and in those days politicians got about #400, which was somewhere around 10 times average weekly earnings. We have all, for various reasons, gone backwards. No doubt, that is perfectly right. However, given the level of salaries in other areas such as in legal firms, given the very large amounts that can be made at the Bar when a good Queen's Counsel-not an outstanding Queen's Counsel, not one of the high fliers-can earn around $500,000 a year, it is not surprising that it is difficult to recruit. It is imperative that we get the best people for the Bench. The reason for that is simple: the quality of justice depends on the quality of the judiciary and unless we get the best lawyers going onto the Bench the quality of justice will suffer and that means individuals suffer, because individuals are the people who make up the great bulk of the work that goes before courts, not vast corporations although they have their very big cases. The daily grind of litigation is made up of individual Australians trying to get justice out of the system.

I would like to take up something that the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) said when he spoke about the high price of justice. He is, of course, perfectly right. It was once said that justice is open to everyone like the doors of the Ritz Hotel in London. We thought that with legal aid and with more modern means of dealing with cases those days were behind us. In fact, they are not. I have one piece of advice to give to anybody who is thinking of litigating and who is not very wealthy or backed by a very wealthy organisation: `Do not litigate. You cannot afford it'. To go to court these days for a case involving, for example, $100,000 or $200,000 may cost you on your side alone daily legal fees-paid up front, not after the event-of $5,000 to $8,000. For a case that goes for five days, as a not too complex case over a contract could easily go, the figures are obvious. It does not pay to litigate. It can be a terrifying experience to be caught up in the system because if one is an average person who is borne down by the cost of litigation one is also ground down by the delays of the courts. In this country we have a system of justice which is limping along and which denies entry to the average Australian because the average Australian, unless backed by a wealthy organisation or fortunate enough to get legal aid, cannot afford the price of entry.

I agree with what the honourable member for Menzies said on the subject of royal commissions. On this different subject I point to the procedure that is involved in royal commissions. A commissioner is appointed. His terms of reference are given to him. He discharges his terms of reference through hearings, through the examination of evidence and through listening to submissions and arriving at a decision. That decision is recorded characteristically in a lengthy report which is brought back to Parliament. If it is a subject of political concern, it is debated here. We have had those debates in this chamber where judges have been criticised because they came to a decision which was politically unpopular. That is the point the honourable member for Menzies makes. It is a very important one because judges then get brought in, whether they like it or not, to the political arena. As that happens, so their authority and independence is devalued.

There may be cases of a completely non-political kind-for example, an inquiry into a criminal matter where it is thought that justice was not originally done-where it might be appropriate to have a judge conduct the inquiry. I have my doubts about that because there are many practising lawyers who could do it. But, save for those very special cases, judges should stay completely outside areas of the kind the honourable member for Menzies referred to. He mentioned Mr Justice Einfeld speaking about genocide. The truth is that a judge is no better qualified and is sometimes less well qualified, because of the constrained way in which he must live as a judge, to make social judgments and these value judgments than are other people.

As has been made plain, we support what has been said. We support the increases of judges' salaries. I welcome the fact that a determination is now going to be made rather than a recommendation, so that it will then be up to Parliament to disallow a determination made by the Remuneration Tribunal. If we are going to have a system of justice in this country that we can be proud of, we need to have the best quality lawyers as judges, with that additional and essential ingredient of humility and concern for justice. We need to have a system that the ordinary Australian can enter without fear that costs and time and the wear of being involved in the judicial process will be destructive of his life. At the moment we do not have that system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those members of the House who have participated in this debate. I welcome the support of the Opposition for the Judicial and Statutory Officers Remuneration Legislation Amendment Bill. I welcome the support that has been indicated for the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: As the House will be aware, the Bill implements increases in remuneration for the members of the Federal judiciary. The Government rejected substantial salary increases recommended for the Federal judiciary in the Remuneration Tribunal's 1988 review. At that time the Government asked the members of the Tribunal to prepare a special report on appropriate remuneration for the judiciary in the current wage fixing context. The report recommended that an inequity in remuneration between Federal and State court judges be rectified by the granting of a 16 per cent increase, that the August 1988 national wage increases of 3 per cent and $10 a week be applied, and that expenses of office allowance be absorbed into salaries. The Government announced on 13 July this year its acceptance of those recommendations and its intention to legislate to implement them.

The Bill adjusts travelling allowances in accordance with the recommendations in the 1988 review. The increases in the remuneration are to apply from 1 March 1989, consistent with the Tribunal's special report. The Bill also implements the Government's decision to equate the remuneration of judges of the Family Court with that of the Federal Court. There is no longer any justification for them to be paid lower levels of remuneration, especially as the Federal Court is now able to refer certain matters to the Family Court.

The Tribunal will be empowered in the future to determine judicial remuneration rather than make recommendations, as at present, in respect of judges and judicial officeholders. This will bring the setting of judicial remuneration into line with the setting of remuneration for all other officers within the Tribunal's jurisdiction except Ministers. As is the case for these other officers, determinations will be subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament. I have asked the members of the Tribunal to undertake a further examination of judicial salaries in light of the August 1989 national wage case decision. This review will also assess the appropriateness of the relativities of remuneration between Federal Court judges and a number of statutory officeholders.

To respond to a few of the matters raised by honourable members who participated in the debate, a question was raised about the level of increases for judges being proposed by the Government and supported by this House compared with the claim by the pilots for a 30 per cent wage increase without any productivity improvement and without any acceptance of arbitration or undertaking to work within the national wage case guidelines. The increases in the judicial remuneration were recommended by the members of an independent tribunal and are consistent with national wage case principles. It is against these principles that claims for wage increases for members of the general work force are assessed. The national wage principles provide for the resolution of inequities existing where employees performing similar work are paid dissimilar rates of pay without good reason. That was the anomalies and inequities proposal that was put, in addition to the other national wage increase factors, in respect of the increases now being legislated for the judiciary.

On the other hand, the pilots have sought to pursue their claims ouside the framework of the independent Industrial Relations Commission. If the pilots believe that they have a genuine claim, they could have pursued that claim within the Commission and have it tested against the national wage fixing principles. The fact is that they have resolutely refused to accept arbitration or to work within the national wage case guidelines, as do almost all other wage and salary earners in this country.

The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) raised the problem of attracting suitable counsel to the judiciary. The increases that are being provided will go some way towards attracting suitable counsel to the judiciary. The increases that are being provided will go some way towards attracting the best possible people to the Bench and to retaining those people. On the whole, the increases are fairly substantial. The balance between the need for continued restraint and the maintenance of adequate salaries for the Federal judiciary will be kept under review by the Remuneration Tribunal. As I mentioned earlier, a further examination of judicial remuneration will be undertaken by the Tribunal in light of the August 1989 national wage case decision.

It is not tenable for judicial remuneration to be raised to the level received by many senior members of the Bar, as pointed out by the honourable member for Menzies; nor is it necessary to do so as remuneration is but one factor relevant to those who seek judicial office. Nevertheless, the increases resulting from this Bill will assist in narrowing the gap.

I conclude by bringing to the attention of the House the fact that since the Bill was introduced I have received constitutional advice which has necessitated amendments to the Bill. I have also taken the opportunity to make some other technical amendments. I will be dealing with those matters at the committee stage. I commend the Bill to the House.

The amendments are designed to introduce some technical amendments and to implement increases in allowances for the President and members of the Inter-State Commission, as recommended by the Remuneration Tribunal in its last review. One of the technical amendments provides that determinations of judicial remuneration will not come into operation until after the period allowed for parliamentary disallowance of the determination has elapsed.

The Bill as introduced gave the Remuneration Tribunal power to make determinations of judicial remuneration. This power is subject under the Remuneration Tribunal Act to disallowance by the Parliament. The Constitution provides that judicial remuneration shall not be diminished during continuance in office. Therefore, disallowance of a determination already in operation would be potentially inconsistent with the Constitution. TALK.START.PARA: —Of the three pieces of legislation being debated cognately, the first listed is the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989. Essentially it deals with the measures which will require major employers to remit pay as you earn (PAYE) tax deductions twice each month instead of monthly, as occurs at present. Changes to the conditions under which quarterly provisional tax payments are to be made are also included in the Bill. The second Bill being debated is the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 which deals with the rates applicable to various classes of income tax payer. The third Bill under discussion is the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989. Each of the Bills reflects the stated intention of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at the time he brought down his 1989 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention to speak at length on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989, as I have raised this matter in the Parliament previously. It is regrettable that this amendment will do nothing to stop the grossing up effect on franked dividend income. To enable a better understanding of that effect it might be useful to give a simple example. As it now stands, and this has been the case since company tax imputation was adopted, a fully franked dividend of, say, $61 generates a Medicare levy impost of $1.25, or 2.049 per cent. From that illustration it can be seen that the Medicare levy is far in excess of what is commonly supposed when it comes to collections of franked dividend income. In effect, large sums are being reefed from shareholders by this Government under a pretext. Apparently, that sort of cheating by the Government is quite acceptable. One can imagine the outrage that would be expressed if it worked the other way, and that under some pretext a large body of taxpayers were able to escape their obligation to pay all or part of a tax impost. That is just one example among many of the double standards adopted by the Government and its Treasurer.

In the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 we see further evidence, if further evidence were needed, of the Government's determination to reap tax benefits as a result of its economic and fiscal mismanagement. Although it might be argued that tax relief, whenever granted and by whatever means achieved, is acceptable, there is much more to these measures than that simplistic proposition.
