TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. By the end of this financial year, after a mere seven years in government, total taxation revenue will have increased from $40.7 billion to $91.3 billion. The table clearly shows that revenue to this grasping Government has soared by a massive 123 per cent over the period of its term in office while inflation as measured by the consumer price index is likely to be in the vicinity of only 85 per cent. Exploitation of Australian taxpayers under this Labor regime by any measure has exploded. Is it any wonder that at long last a sizeable surplus is now possible?

SPEECH.PARA: Any reasonable examination of the table brings into stark relief the consequences of inflation and associated bracket creep, even if new taxes introduced over the last seven years are eliminated from consideration for the purpose of this debate. Of course, new taxes cannot, and should not, be ignored when any examination of Labor's overall taxation record is made. To do so would be to ignore over $6.5 billion in revenue raised from new tax measures alone. Making up that mammoth impost wrought by new taxes-not increases, but new taxes-are estimated collections for the current year from the capital gains tax, the Medicare levy, the prescribed payments system, superannuation funds and fringe benefits taxes. But it is the deliberating effects of bracket creep which is worthy of special comment, given that the Bill is all about giving a fraction of the tax relief possible, if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer had not gorged themselves on the manna extorted from Australian taxpayers by deliberately inflationary and inept fiscal management. Even so, over half of that, which would have been collected this year if tax scales and rates had remained unchanged, will be recovered as a result of wage and salary inflation and its effects in this financial year alone. That is apart from the massive amounts of additional tax paid by all taxpayers over the last six years. There will be no relief from that.

The Treasurer's message is quite clear: we can kiss that goodbye. What is more, taxpayers can kiss about half of this year's tax cuts goodbye too, because bracket creep, which forces taxpayers to pay higher marginal rates on extra dollars earned, will mean that even more hard earned income will find its way into the already well-lined pockets of this Government. The Government will slug people even more by way of indexed excise levied on petrol and other things. It is a sad truth that these tax measures will not lead to sustainable improvements in living standards because of the effects of high interest rates, continuing high taxation and inflation. Sadly, the opposite will be the case.

In contrast to the unmitigated greed of the present Government, the coalition parties intend to redistribute additional revenue gained from the consequences of inflation in the form of bracket creep back to taxpayers once the quantum is identified. We will do this on election to government because the taxpayers of Australia need a break from the endless grind of more and more taxation and less and less reward for effort.

In turning now to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, I remind the House that it deals with two major areas: the twice-monthly remittance of PAYE deductions and measures to do with provisional tax. The pay as you earn requirements will compel group employers with a history of annual remittances exceeding $5m to remit sums deducted from wages, salaries, commissions and the like twice each month instead of only once, as at present, and all employers with annual remittances of less than $5m. For those affected deductions made during the first 14 days of any month will be remitted not later than the twenty-first day of the same month. Deductions made from the fifteenth day of any month will have to be paid no later than the seventh day of the succeeding month.

For employers, the unpaid tax collectors of the Commonwealth, this will considerably erode cash flows. That will not be of any concern to the Treasurer; after all, in his Budget Speech, when discussing outrageous proposals to advance collection of company taxes even before the companies know the extent of profitability, he said that companies presently enjoy `an interest free loan from the Government' because they had not previously been required to pay 85 per cent of notional tax commencing within a couple of weeks of the end of a financial year. That is a measure of both the ignorance and arrogance of the Treasurer. So it is that he will not have considered the implications for affected employers required to remit PAYE deductions bimonthly.

The Treasurer and others in the Government would not be aware-or, if they are, could not care less-that most cash flow projections are based on monthly cycles. Affected employers have not received payment for the wage and salary component in goods and services sold to clients under present arrangements, let alone under those to be required. The significance for cash flows is that employers will be reduced to working to a fortnightly cycle complicated by the fact that pay days under the first and new requirement will fall on any date between the first and fourteenth day of that month. Although the unpaid tax collecting employer will know that tax will have to be remitted before the twenty-first, the amount cannot be anticipated. This uncertainty is already present with monthly remittances; it will be exacerbated by the twice-monthly requirement.

Once again higher administrative costs to employers will be incurred at the mere whim of a Labor government. The costs of administration to be met by the Australian Taxation Office will also be increased. The Taxation Office will have to allocate resources and funds to police the change. When remittances are not received by the due date, follow-up will be necessary and decisions will have to be taken about the need to levy penalties. Presumably that will occur only after notices have been given or inquiries made or both. Yet there is no estimate of this increased cost to the Australian Taxation Office in the explanatory memorandum. There can be no doubt that there will be additional administrative costs to the Australian Taxation Office, yet this Government, which, when in opposition, made great play of calling for cost impact statements and which has welshed increasingly on the principle as it grows tired in government, does not even bother to tell us what the additional administration cost will be. The Government probably does not even know.

On its own, that might be just another example of the tiredness or laziness, if you like, of the Government. However, if we look elsewhere in the explanatory memorandum we see that the Government claims as a virtue for these measures that in one case public debt interest will be $20m less this financial year. There is some reason to doubt that figure if only because it appears to be exactly offset by interest to be incurred as a consequence of reductions in revenue expected not to be collected following one of the changes to provisional taxes. One measure is expected to reduce public debt interest by $20m this year and the other to increase it by the same amount. That appears to be too much of a coincidence. It is more likely to be the product of some creative accounting by the Government. If it is not, I will welcome the opportunity to retract if the Government tables its calculations and they are found to be reasonable.

In the meantime the claimed or estimated public debt interest component in the financial impact statement at the top of page 2 in the explanatory memorandum continues to intrigue. Remember that the financial impact statement on this occasion not only is about additional revenue or less revenue but also includes movements in the public debt interest which, because of changed public service borrowing requirements, will either fall or increase because additional or less revenue is collected as the case may be.

I now want to focus on the interest component as a separate and identified part of the projected financial impact. The financial impact statement sets out a reduction of $160m in revenue anticipated as a result of the uplift factor for the calculation of provisional tax in 1989-90, but no public debt interest figure is given. The financial impact statement does not represent the product of a tired, lazy government; it represents blatant deceit. For the year 1989-90 the gain to revenue from twice-monthly PAYE remittances is given as $550m, enabling a $20m reduction of public debt interest. When it comes to changes to payment of provisional taxes, we are not even given an estimate of how much less revenue will ensue. It will be less because we are told that the public debt interest for 1989 will as a result increase by $20m. If expressed in commercial terms, the effects of the first two changes in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 are in one case an additional $550m principal, accompanied by a saving of $20m interest, and in the second case, where we are not told the amount of principal although principal there must be, interest on that unknown amount will be an additional $20m.

The third measure in this Bill which will have notable financial impact and which is included also in the financial impact statement concerns provisional tax too. By reducing the amount to be added onto the assessable income of taxpayers subjected to provisional tax to 10 per cent from the present 11 or 12 per cent, the explanatory memorandum only stipulates an estimated reduction in revenue to be collected of some $160m in 1989-90. Using the formula adopted for the other and previous measures in the same Bill, there should be an estimate of the additional public debt interest. There is not.

So we are grappling with treble standards, not double standards. In the first case the effects on the revenue and public debt interest are given; in the second case only the effect on public debt interest is given; and in the third case only the effect on revenue is given. What sort of madness is that? This from a Treasurer who offers himself as an authority on the costings of the coalition parties' policies yet cannot get those flowing from his own legislation right, even with the vast resources of government at his command.

I refer again to the financial impact statement and the other two Bills that are being debated cognately, namely, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989, which all appear on the same page of the explanatory memorandum, listed one after another, but to which different criteria are applied. I will deal first with the Medicare changes, because they are comparatively insignificant. Revenue will be reduced by $10m, but no estimate is given of the ensuing increase in public debt interest. The daddy of them all has to do with the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2). That Bill makes changes which, we have been told on other occasions, will reduce revenue by up to $4.9 billion. That was not a slip of the tongue-$4.9 billion. That sum is not even mentioned in the financial impact statement.

One would have thought that the Treasurer and his Government would make sure that the Government's changes to the rates of income on which personal income tax is to be paid would be shouted loud and wide. That is very strange indeed. As Professor Julius Sumner Miller used to ask: Why is it so? Why, indeed. Could it be that, because public debt interest was quoted as part of the financial impact flowing from another Bill cognately under consideration, the estimated reduction in revenue to be collected would have to be accompanied by a concomitant figure for increased public debt interest, in order to be consistent? If the estimated reduction of up to $4.9 billion was subjected to the same test, that is, increased public debt interest calculated on the amount by which the revenue is to be reduced, a very handsome sum indeed would have to be included in the financial impact statement.

To make an intelligent assessment of what it might be, perhaps we should look at the first item in the accompanying financial impact statement, at the top of page 2 of the memorandum. A figure of $550m is cited as producing a change of $20m to public debt interest. If that $550m is multiplied by nine, one arrives at a figure close to the $4.9 billion mentioned. On that admittedly imprecise approach, the increase in public debt interest this year would approximate $180m. There you have it. That is another example of this Government's mad, twisted thinking-and brought about by what? It is brought about, it seems, by the selective citing in financial impact statements of a public debt interest factor applied to separate, but selected, outcomes. If a public debt interest factor is appropriate in one case, it is also relevant to all legislation, not just that chosen for special treatment. Think of the possibilities. Each and every piece of legislation brought before the Parliament which varies either expenditure or revenue has some financial impact which, if the Government lives up to its rhetoric, should properly be estimated in the accompanying explanatory memorandum. That is all that is reasonably expected. Sadly, it is not always done.

To go one illogical step further, because either revenue is to be less or expenditure higher, or alternatively, more revenue is to be raised or expenditure reduced, ensuing public debt interest becomes part of the equation. Although not all of it is to be the subject of legislation, but given that expenditure this year is estimated to increase by $4.625 billion, my strong recommendation to the Government is to forget this nonsense. All that is required in a financial impact statement is the net difference between the prime increase or reduction measured against what applied previously-nothing more, nothing less. We know that the Government has placed us in hock up to our eyeballs and that, because of that, less revenue or higher expenditure means the Government will have to dip into taxpayers' pockets even more to pay the interest bill.

I return now to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 and its provisions which relate to provisional tax. These amendments are incomprehensible. Most tax specialists would not be practising solely in the provisional tax area and most practitioners who advise on provisional tax will be quite unable to read these amendments. For example, look at paragraph 221 ycaa (1) (b) at the top of page 8 of the Bill. Bearing in mind the continued rhetoric of the Government and the thoroughly supportable call for more legible law, it is not appropriate to release more in this form without also providing very detailed accompanying examples, and perhaps even software packages, to assist in the application of the law. The capacity for the average tax agent to misapply this law will be very significant indeed. These changes to provisional taxes, to the extent that they are welcome, still leave much to be desired.

For example, there will be little consolation for a widow who lives in my electorate. She is living on income from $300,000 capital invested. Last year, the interest on that investment earned her $38,000. However, her total tax liability is $24,330.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is pretty hard up!

—As I was saying, her total tax liability on $38,000 is $24,330, including $13,900 provisional tax for 1989-90. In answer to the honourable member's ignorance, I point out that the consequence of that is that she is left with little more than $13,000 on which to live, and because she is assets rich, she is not entitled to fringe benefits or other support. The end result is that the 63-year-old widow, whose financial circumstances I have outlined, will probably be unable to keep her capital intact, because this year at least she will have to make do with $13,000. That might be considered a princely sum, and when measured against the income of others living in abject poverty because of this Government's ineptitude--
—Poverty. It is your policy.
—It is also a classic example of how living standards have been eroded under Labor. My parrot-like friend opposite would do well to remember that.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move to the amendment which has been circulated in my name. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that the Government's record high tax burden has inflicted considerable pain on Australians, who face little incentive to work, to invest and to save.'.

In speaking to that amendment, I turn again to the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. Although we in the coalition parties recognise the need for tax relief, we have also consistently maintained that unfunded tax cuts are irresponsible. They undoubtedly and measurably fuel demand. That is readily evidenced by data published on economic activity in recent months. Despite the current record high interest rates, data shows that import growth, employment and retail sales continued to grow. In short, the unfunded tax cuts have sabotaged the Government's only policy response to our chronic economic problems. That response is high interest rates. Australians continue to suffer under high interest rates while they receive some short-lived relief in the form of unfunded tax cuts which are quickly chewed up by high interest rates and inflation. Despite these tax cuts, the Government remains the highest taxing government in postwar history, and I refer the House to the table that I have already had incorporated.

In contrast to the Government's policy of unfunded tax cuts, the Opposition's recently released Economic Action Plan includes funded tax relief aimed specifically at families. Working families have borne the brunt of the burden of the Government's economic mismanagement. They have been ignored for too long. The Opposition's tax initiatives recognise the additional costs facing taxpayers with children and the costs facing working parents in terms of child-care. We have also eased the income testing of the dependent spouse rebate to enable dependent spouses to earn income without being subjected to extreme penalties. In stark contrast to the Government's policy, our tax relief measures are fully funded by expenditure cuts. The result is that the Opposition has a tighter fiscal policy than the Government. We have outlays to gross domestic product scheduled to be at the lowest level for 25 years and the largest Budget surplus since comparable measures have been kept.

The amendment I have moved is also relevant to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989. The changes to PAYE remittances will have the effect of bringing forward revenue from 1990-91 to 1989-90. We have described this-quite properly, in my view-as an example of the Treasurer's `innovative accounting', designed to magnify the size of the Budget surplus in this financial year. These changes mean that large businesses are being penalised to obtain an apparent increase in the Government's surplus. However, the Government's stated objective of reducing the frequency of PAYE remittances from small businesses is welcomed, as it has been a source of continuing concern to the small business community and should result in more financial flexibility for these enterprises. I commend the amendment to the House in the terms expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to enter this cognate debate because it allows me, again, to compare and show how starkly different the Opposition's and the Government's taxation policies are. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) said a lot about the Economic Action Plan document and what it means for the future and families. He said a lot about the taxation system. He said that a coalition government would repeal many of the initiatives enacted by the Government. I will turn to those matters in a moment. First I want to remind the House, briefly, of a couple of the issues that have been raised in the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989 deals with the twice-monthly remittance of pay as you earn (PAYE) tax instalment deductions, quarterly provisional tax and provisional tax itself. The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) deals with the income tax rates for the 1989-90 financial year and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989 imposes the Medicare levy for 1989-90. With respect to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, the Government has considered the options and has determined that the twice-monthly PAYE remittance is an appropriate amendment to the policy settings that the Government has on the collection of tax. The honourable member for Curtin said that the Government has provided little tax relief. Because PAYE taxpayers are the ones most affected by the measures before us, let me remind the honourable member what the Government has done in terms of tax relief. In 1983 the mob on the other side was in government. When the former Government lost office this country was left with a top marginal tax rate of 60c in the dollar and a bottom marginal tax rate of about 30c in the dollar. Under this Government the top marginal rate is going to be 47c and the bottom marginal rate 21c. Those are just the marginal tax rates.

More importantly, the stark differences between the philosophies of honourable members on this side of the House and those of honourable members opposite are more aptly demonstrated by the Government's commitment to removing the rorts in the system that have operated for so long and, additionally, to seek some advantage for the people of Australia-ordinary PAYE taxpayers-who do not play the share markets and get major capital gains and who do not have free lunches and big cars being driven around for them by chauffeurs. The fringe benefits tax was able to fix that up. We recognised the need to do something about it.

What have we seen with economic action man on the other side with the Economic Action Plan? He has walked away from the fringe benefits tax. Under his policy it will stay. What about the capital gains tax? Do honourable members remember that well-worn phrase, `lock, stock and barrel'? It is not a firm of solicitors and it is long gone because the capital gains tax is also retained in this Economic Action Plan from the economic action man opposite. Where is there any reference in that document and in the contribution of the honourable member for Curtin to the major problems facing the economy-that is, the debt and interest rates? They are not mentioned in the Economic Action Plan. The Opposition's non-consideration, non-mention and non-determination in the Economic Action Plan document of any alternatives is tantamount to endorsing this Government's economic policies. As I said when it was released, the document is an absolute sham.

Let us talk about PAYE taxpayers-those people who have tax taken out of their pay because they are part of a fair and equitable system. My honourable friend from Curtin said that there has been no tax relief for those poor people and that this miserable Government has increased its tax over a long period. I agree with him that revenue collected by the Government from PAYE taxpayers particularly has increased. It has increased because an additional 1.6 million people have a job and are now paying income tax, many for the first time ever. Since this Government came to office in 1983 an additional 1.6 million people have a job. Who could ever forget the 750,000 people-I think that was the number-who were consigned to the unemployment scrap heap in the last 12 months of the former Government.

Who was the economic adviser back then who told the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) what he should do? It was none other than the present shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), the person who has developed some new-found sympathy for PAYE taxpayers. He is the person who drives a Ferrari, has a restaurant in Sydney, has bought property in Bowral and is looking to buy something in Canberra. He now has new-found sympathy for PAYE taxpayers. He sends people in here today, because he has not an opportunity to do so, to try to convince the people of Australia that the Opposition's policy is to offer them tax relief-a flatter, two-tiered system. When asked what it means the honourable member for Wentworth says, `We will tell you when we get into government. Trust us'. We trusted those opposite in 1983 and the people of Australia trusted them before that. What did they get for their trust? They got 10.5 per cent unemployment and an inflation rate of 10 per cent-plus. Many millions of people were put out of work and the Medicare system did not exist. Two million people were not covered by any form of health insurance. One of the Bills before us today seeks to fix the Medicare levy for 1989-90.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it changed since 1986?

—My colleague reminds me that it has not changed since 1986. Interestingly, during the deliberations and consideration of the Economic Action Plan a view was put around, which I have not seen denied, that the hidden agenda on how to pay for some of the things contained in the document was the elimination of Medicare. SPEECH.PARA: One of the centrepieces of the policy-the so-called tax relief that is included-is that of child-care. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill propose changes to our income tax system. Unfortunately, each of the Bills provides only cosmetic changes to an increasingly complex and burdensome system. It is burdensome not only in the financial liabilities it imposes on individuals and families but also in its administrative requirements. Evidence of this administrative maze was really confirmed by the Commissioner of Taxation in a speech he gave on 26 May this year to the Australian Society of Accountants, when he noted that 65 to 70 per cent of income tax returns are lodged by tax agents.

SPEECH.PARA: So complex has the system become that an increasing number of average Australians find it necessary, in order that they can be charged only the appropriate level of taxation, to pay a fee to have their tax return completed. There was a day when the system was simpler and many people were able, with confidence, to complete their own tax returns, knowing that they were paying what was due and were not being charged any more than was their fair liability. It is time for reform. Despite all the protestations of the Treasurer and the henchmen behind him, the reform has not been completed. Many of the actions of the present Government have caused problems and brought about the need for real reform. We must restore incentives for Australians to work harder and to exercise initiative and enterprise. This can be done only by abolishing the current five-step income tax system and introducing a flatter, simpler system such as the two-step rates structure that the next Liberal-National Party government is committed to introduce in its first term in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the rates?

—That is an interesting matter, and I will come to that question later in my speech. We have indicated that we will not go on doing each year what the honourable member's Government has done every year, which is to take more in real terms from individual taxpayers because of the effect of bracket creep. Every now and again the Government gives back some bracket creep, in an ad hoc way, but in fact it fails to fully return bracket creep to Australian taxpayers. To begin with, we should determine how the cost of government should be shared amongst Australian taxpayers. Most Australians would agree that tax should be shared according to the principle of capacity to pay. How then does one measure a taxpayer's capacity to pay?

SPEECH.PARA: According to the present Government, capacity to pay is determined by the level of a taxpayer's income and by that test alone. Inadequate allowance is made for the cost that is borne by taxpayers of supporting dependants, whether the dependants are their spouses, children, adult student children, other family members, or even friends. The relief that is now available is much less than that provided to those who are dependent upon the public sector. Similarly, tax liability is not adjusted to allow for the costs of taxpayers who discharge their own or their dependants' social expenditures, which would otherwise be discharged by the public sector. For example, taxpayers who choose to educate their children at an independent school face a double cost of educating their own children and paying part of the cost of educating other people's children in the state system. The same double cost is imposed on taxpayers who choose to take out private health insurance or to provide a retirement income for themselves or for their dependants.

If tax liability is truly to reflect the principle of capacity to pay, it must be adjusted to adequately compensate for the cost of maintaining dependants and the cost of undertaking private social expenditure which, if not undertaken privately, would be borne by the general body of taxpayers. That adjustment could be achieved by making tax credits available to those taxpayers. The amount of the tax credit should be equivalent to the cost that would otherwise have been borne by the public sector. For example, taxpayers who support dependent children should receive tax credits that are equal to the allowance that is received by children who are dependent upon the public sector. Taxpayers who educate their children in the private education system should receive a tax credit that is equal to the public sector cost of educating those same children.

The economic and tax policy of the Liberal and National parties, which was released earlier this month, outlines a series of child tax rebates that recognise the increased costs to families of bringing up children. Those tax rebates are a step in the right direction towards achieving a capacity to pay tax system. I would like to see a future Liberal-National Party government merge all payments for children into a single tax rebate or tax credit that would be cashable by the principal carer of the children to the extent that it would not be utilised in exempting that care-giver from tax that would otherwise be payable. In the long run, I would like those rebates or credits to be increased to the amount of government support for children who are dependent upon the public sector.

Currently, family allowances are regarded by many people as a welfare expenditure. Paid to some, they are truly categorised and correctly categorised as such. However, for the majority they are wrongly categorised, being treated as welfare payments. In the majority of cases, either the tax liability of the recipient of the allowances or the tax liability of her family is greater than the family allowance that she receives. That is an example of the lack of integration between our social security system and our tax system.

The social security system should be divided into two different sections: the one that pays out truly welfare payments, and the other that makes allowances to people who themselves or through their families pay tax that is greater than the allowance that they receive. Indeed, if one became very sophisticated in this approach, one should do it not only on a year-by-year accounting basis but also on a life cycle basis and should regard the tax social security system as being a life cycle adjustment between the times when people can afford to pay tax to provide them and ensure that they have the resources when they need to meet the costs of providing for their retirement incomes, looking after children and so on. Rather than treating the family allowance as a welfare payment, we should consider it as a capacity to pay tax rebate for credit that acknowledges the costs of supporting dependent children.

A Liberal-National Party government will increase the threshold for the dependent spouse rebate and decrease the rate at which it is withdrawn. That will increase the number of taxpayers who are entitled to claim a dependent spouse rebate for their spouses. In time we should consider making that spouse rebate fully cashable for those families who would like it that way so that it can be paid as a tax refund or a tax credit to the dependent spouse. That would reduce the dependency of spouses on their partners by providing them with a degree of personal economic independence to which I believe each individual is entitled.

Another aspect of the tax system that should be reformed is the measurement of tax expenditures by the Department of the Treasury. Currently in Australia, the individual is the unit upon which income tax liability is assessed. The tax free threshold is not considered as a tax expenditure. Because the individual is the tax unit, modifications in tax liability because of dependent care responsibilities are treated as tax expenditures. In the tax expenditure statement of 1988, when referring to the inclusion as a tax expenditure of the modifications in tax liability because of dependent care responsibilities, the Treasury noted:
. . . this is not to say that such provisions are not defensible design features of the tax system.

Those defensible design features should be incorporated in the benchmark tax structure. It is anomalous that tax exemptions on the subsistence level income for a taxpayer are considered as part of the benchmark tax structure but tax exemptions on the subsistence level income for a taxpayer's dependants are not considered as part of that same benchmark tax structure. To be consistent, either they both should be included in the benchmark tax structure and thus not be considered as tax expenditures or they should both be excluded from the benchmark tax structure and therefore be considered as tax expenditures. I personally support the approach of including the capacity to pay principles in the benchmark tax structure. If that were to be the case, because of dependent care responsibilities, those modifications in the tax liability of an individual taxpayer would not be treated as tax expenditures.

Another insidious problem that has plagued our present tax system is the effect of bracket creep on an individual taxpayer. Bracket creep occurs when increases in a taxpayer's income force that taxpayer into a higher marginal tax range because there has been a failure to index the tax thresholds. In 1982-83, taxpayers on average earnings of $17,630 in the dollars of that year would have paid $4,038 in income tax, or 22.9 per cent of their income. Using the 1989-90 Budget forecast for wages growth of 7 per cent, average annual earnings for this period will be $28,216. The tax payable under the new Keating tax formula would be $6,813. Thus, for 1989-90 taxpayers on average annual earnings will pay not 22.9 per cent of their income but 24.1 per cent of their income in tax. The tax burden on such individuals has been increased by 5.2 per cent since 1982-83, which was the last year of the Fraser Liberal Government. Similarly, this year, taxpayers on average annual earnings who have a dependent spouse and two dependent children will pay an estimated 16 per cent of their income in tax, compared with only 14.1 per cent in 1982-83. The tax burden on such families has been increased by Labor by 13.5 per cent during the lifetime of its government.

The two examples I have just described are evidence that the tax cuts given by the Labor Government have not compensated taxpayers for the erosion of their incomes due to bracket creep, yet the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when announcing the July round of tax cuts in the April 1989 economic statement had the gall to claim that the new tax structure `more than offsets what is known as fiscal drag or bracket creep'. He went on:
In other words, personal income taxpayers will now be paying less than if we had indexed the tax scales for inflation since 1983.

We all know that statistics can be used selectively to tell almost any story. Clearly the Treasurer has misled the Australian people with his outrageous claim. It appears he has massaged the data, to tell a story he would like the public to hear and believe, rather than given a fair representation of how bracket creep under his administration has affected the typical taxpayer on average annual earnings.

The Liberal and National parties have not shirked tough decisions in the area of bracket creep. We have announced that we will not allow Labor's bracket creep tax grab to continue. The next Liberal-National Party government will commit itself to forgoing the increase in revenue because of bracket creep. It is estimated that over the period 1982-83 to 1989-90 the real level of income tax collected from individuals will have increased by 3.2 per cent as a consequence of bracket creep. In dollar terms this is substantially in excess of $1 billion additional revenue collected because of the present Government's failure to adjust fully for bracket creep. It has given ad hoc relief, but in giving that relief it has been most unfair to average working Australian families.

Another aspect of the current tax system which is in need of reform is the Medicare levy. Today we have before us the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill which seeks to increase the threshold from which the 1.25 per cent levy is to be imposed. The Bill provides me with an opportunity to draw to the attention of the House the deceptiveness involved in the imposition of the Medicare levy. Indeed, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) in his speech to the House said the Government had held the Medicare levy at 1.25 per cent. So what? What does the Medicare levy mean? It means very little. It is really part of the overall tax burden.

Many Australians believe that the services provided under Medicare-that is, the 85 per cent of the schedule fee for medical services and public hospital accommodation-are paid for with the revenue collected from the Medicare levy, but they are wrong. Unfortunately, that is not the case. Using the data contained in Budget Statement No. 1 it can be shown that the Medicare levy in fact pays approximately one-third of the cost of the services provided under Medicare. The remaining cost of providing the services under Medicare is met from general revenue. The Government has chosen to provide a public health care system; now let it be honest about its costs. If the Government were to set the Medicare levy so that it fully funded the Medicare system, it would need almost three times the current levy of 1.25 per cent-that is, a levy of approximately 3.5 per cent. If we did it on a revenue neutral basis and were honest with the Australian people and the users of the health care system, we would have a 3.5 per cent Medicare levy and the general tax structure rates would be 2.25 per cent lower than they currently are. But they need to be brought much lower still, and I am sure they will be reduced as a Liberal-National Party government moves to a two-step rate structure.

The use of the Medicare levy is Labor's devious way of disguising the true costs of the provision of Medicare. Today I have drawn the attention of the House to the urgent need for reform of the tax system. The next Liberal government is committed to providing a flatter tax system with two rates; to introducing child tax rebates and child-care rebates; to increasing the eligibility threshold for the dependent spouse rebate and reducing the withdrawal rate; to increasing the tax free threshold for superannuants; to introducing tax reductions for those who take out retirement savings accounts and are entering the work force for the first time or are casual, part time, itinerant employees; and to abolishing Labor's capital gains tax and replacing it with a speculative gains tax which taxes capital gains on a sliding scale over five years.

Changes such as these have my enthusiastic support, and in particular I would like to see the proceeds arising from bracket creep used to implement a two-step rate structure. My view is that the tax free threshold should be lifted from $5,100 so that it is well clear of the amount paid to age and other pensioners. I would suggest that the tax free threshold should be of the order of one-third of average weekly earnings. If that were done and the opening marginal rate of tax were set at 30c in the dollar, that rate should be continued until the level of income reached is equal to average weekly earnings. In other words, there will be no tax payable up to, in today's dollars, about $8,400, with 30c in the dollar being payable from $8,400 up to about $25,000. Some may say that means we increase the 21c rate to 30c but the fact is that if we lifted the threshold, everyone would pay less tax than they do now.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about those on $100,000?

—They would pay less tax, too. It is interesting that the Minister should make that interjection because in one sense it has been his Government that has given substantial tax cuts to people on $100,000. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum rate of the levy that may be imposed under the Grape Research Levy Act 1986, which imposes a levy on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice delivered to wineries and other processing establishments. Dried grapes which are leviable under the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971 are exempt. Levy is payable by grapegrowers and by winemakers who grow their own grapes. The proceeds of the levy represent the grapegrowers' contribution to the financing of research on winegrapes and other processed grapes. The Commonwealth matches industry expenditure under the program. A grape and wine research council established under the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 administers the grape research program.

Currently, the maximum rate of the levy under the Grape Research Levy Act is 50c per tonne. The operative rate of the levy was increased to this level with effect from 1 January 1989. This amendment will provide flexibility for the levy to be increased in future, but only if industry so requests.

In May 1988, the Government reaffirmed its commitment to matching rural industry research expenditures up to a ceiling of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production (GVP) of the industry concerned. Subsequently, the Winegrape Growers Council of Australia requested that the maximum rate of the grape research levy be increased to $2 per tonne to enable a phased increase in grape industry research funding. This Bill implements that request, which was supported by each of the nationally representative winemaker organisations.

I want to emphasise that this Bill does not increase the operative rate of levy currently paid by grapegrowers. Increases in operative rates will continue to be set by regulation under the Grape Research Levy Act. There is a specific legislative requirement for industry to be consulted before such increases are implemented. Increasing the maximum rate of the grape research levy will not in itself have a direct impact on government expenditure. The extent to which outlays for grape research increase in the future will depend upon the level of levy increases implemented over time within the higher maximum rate. Growers' funds provided by this levy and matching Commonwealth contributions have placed grape research on a secure long term financial basis. An initial relatively modest expenditure program of about $270,000 in 1987-88 will increase to a budgeted level of $522,000 in the current year. This Bill will facilitate further development of the program commensurate with growers' willingness to contribute additional funds for that purpose.
I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

The Wine Grapes Levy Act 1979 imposes a levy on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice used in the manufacture of wine. The levy has two components-a marketing amount to finance the promotional and regulatory activities of the Corporation, and a research amount which provides industry funding for wine research. The levy is payable by winery proprietors using the equivalent of 20 tonnes or more of fresh grapes per year in winemaking.

The current marketing component of the levy is a flat rate of $4 per tonne of prescribed goods with a cap of $20,000 on levy payments per levy payer. This levy structure has resulted in a disproportionate burden of corporation funding falling upon smaller and medium-sized wineries and considerable potential levy income from larger wineries has been forgone. For example, a proprietor of a winery crushing 5,000 tonnes of grapes pays $4 per tonne or $20,000, but a proprietor of a winery crushing 80,000 tonnes of grapes also pays $20,000 because of the $20,000 levy ceiling. A further weakness in the present levy system is that, because of the levy ceiling, corporate amalgamations have the potential to significantly reduce levy revenue over time. Amendments proposed in this Bill address these issues by abolishing the levy ceiling, introducing a tiered levy system and reducing the threshold tonnage below which levy is not payable.

Under the structure proposed, the levy to fund the Corporation will consist of a flat amount of $200 for each levy payer plus an additional amount depending on the tonnage of grapes used in winemaking. To calculate this additional amount a sliding scale of levy rates will be used. Progressively lower rates will apply as tonnage crushed increases. The maximum rates and initial operative rates of the levy are set out in clause 6 of the Bill. At present proprietors of wineries crushing less than 20 tonnes of prescribed goods per year are exempt from both the marketing and research components of the levy. This Bill proposes to reduce that exemption threshold from 20 tonnes to 10 tonnes.

The levy will continue to be payable on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice used in winemaking. Provision will remain for the operative rates of levy to be changed by regulation. In respect of the marketing component, this will occur only after consideration of any recommendation made to the Minister by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The Corporation must first submit its recommendation to an annual general meeting of the industry and advise the Minister of the voting on any relevant resolution.

The changes provided for in this Bill were requested and are strongly supported by the wine industry. A motion recommending the changes was approved by an 84 per cent majority of votes cast at the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation annual general meeting in February this year. The proposal to reduce the exemption threshold from 20 tonnes to 10 tonnes in respect of the research component of the levy has the support of each of the three national winemaker organisations. It will retain consistency in the exemption level for each component of the levy. The levy changes proposed will also provide substantially increased funding for the Corporation. In 1990-91 estimated levy income will be about $1.16m compared with approximately $750,000 in 1989-90.

Since 1987-88 the Corporation has incurred significant deficits financed through reductions in its reserves. The Corporation has budgeted for a further deficit of about $176,000 in the current year. The increase in levy receipts expected from the changes being implemented this Bill should arrest the erosion of Corporation reserves and be sufficient to cover increased program expenditure by 1990-91. The Corporation was reconstituted in 1986 to improve its accountability to industry and to enable it to operate more effectively and efficiently. The strong industry support for an increase in the level of its funding for the Corporation reflects industry confidence in the Corporation and the programs it has implemented and intends to implement for the industry's benefit.

The Corporation has allocated a high proportion of its resources towards encouraging and servicing, through its export promotion and inspection arrangements, the rapid increase in exports which has occurred in recent years. The value of exports of Australian wine has increased more than fivefold from $20.5m in 1985-86 to $113m in 1988-89. Exports in the current year are expected to be worth $133m.

The wine industry, supported by the Corporation, is working hard to further increase awareness of the quality and value of our wines and to protect the reputation of the industry as a supplier of consistently reliable products. In addition to its promotional programs the Corporation has implemented a compliance monitoring program under which wine samples are analysed for non-permissible additives. Introduction of a label integrity program will further enhance consumer confidence in Australian wine.

Funding changes embodied in this Bill will enable the Corporation to maintain these and other programs from a more secure financial base. The Bill contains appropriate transitional provisions for implementation of the new levy rates from 1 January 1990, which is midway through the normal levy year. This has been done so that the new levy system can apply to the 1990 grape harvest, thereby making additional funding available to the Corporation as soon as possible. The existing levy will apply until 31 December 1989, but a winery proprietor's maximum levy liability in 1989-90 will be limited to what he or she would have incurred had the new levy rates applied throughout 1989-90.

The proposed amendments will have no net effect on Government expenditure. The levy which funds the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation is paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund and an equal amount is appropriated from the Fund for a payment to the Corporation. The revised levy has no additional cost implications for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy as levy collection costs are fully recouped from the industry.
I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to provide the legislative basis for implementation of a wine label integrity program by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. It also makes amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 consequential on amendment of the Wine Grapes Levy Act provided for in an accompanying Bill. In addition this Bill amends penalties in the principal Act.

The wine label integrity program will require wine manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims of the vintage, variety or region or origin of wine and to make those records and the stocks to which they relate available for audit upon request by the Corporation. The purpose of auditing is to help to ensure truth in labelling, thereby increasing consumer confidence in the reliability of wine label claims and enhancing the reputation for quality and value of Australian wine in domestic and export markets.

The label integrity program has been devised and developed by the Corporation at the request of the wine industry. It has the support of each of the three national winemaker organisations and was recommended for adoption by a substantial majority of votes cast at the Corporation's annual general meeting in February 1989. The Wine and Grape Industry Advisory Council, comprising representatives of winemakers and grapegrowers, considers that the program will contribute to meeting the need for regular systematic monitoring of compliance with wine labelling requirements.

The need for legislation by the Commonwealth arises from concern within the wine industry, the Corporation and the Government to protect our reputation for producing sound, good quality wines with accurate product description on labels. Exports of Australian wine have grown from $20.5m in 1985-86 to $113m in 1988-89 and are expected to reach $133m in 1989-90. Continued export expansion is now a key to the industry's future growth and prosperity and protecting the reputation of our wines is essential to achievement of that objective. The Australian wine industry also holds a 97 per cent share of the domestic market for wine. I believe Australian consumers will welcome the implementation of a label integrity program as a further initiative by the wine industry to enhance consumer respect for the local product.

The price which winemakers can obtain for premium wines may invite spurious labelling claims by any producer who has little respect for accuracy in product descriptions. Experience overseas has shown that, in the event of fraudulent winemaking practices and product description by the irresponsible few, export customers tend to avoid wine from all producers of the country affected. Australia's winemakers wish to pre-empt any such damage to their industry, by implementing their own program of industry self-regulation. Knowledge that a system is in place to facilitate detection of breaches should be a strong deterrent to any potential transgressors.

The Bill provides that all wine manufacturers engaged in the manufacture of wine for commercial purposes be required to keep a record of the vintage, variety, region of origin, source of supply and quantity of grape products received for use in making wine. This will enable the Corporation to trace a wine back to the point where grapes from which it was produced were first harvested or juice was first processed. Wine manufacturers who sell or dispose of their wine without any claim as to its vintage, variety or region or origin need not maintain any further records in respect of such wine. For example wine manufacturers who sell their wine as claret, burgundy, moselle or chablis, once they have made records of their intake of grape products, can dispense with further record keeping.

Wine manufacturers who make claims about the vintage, variety or region of origin of a particular wine will need to keep records relating to the production, sales and disposal of all such wines, thereby establishing an `audit trail'. This will enable verification of claims made by wine manufacturers about the pedigree of the wine and enable the Corporation to determine whether or not more wine described as being of a particular variety-say chardonnay-is being sold than could possibly be produced from the available grape supply. Relevant clauses in part 3 of the Bill take account of typical transactions occurring in the wine industry-which include blending of wines, sale of wine to other wineries, transfer of wine between the producing arm and marketing arm of related companies, winemaking under contract, relabelling of wines without labels and cellar door sales. The clauses in each case impose obligations on wine manufacturers to keep records, not on grapegrowers or bottling firms.

The need for record keeping arises from a circumstance believed to be unique to the wine industry-that there is no known technical means of assessing a wine to determine its vintage, variety or region of origin. For most other primary products, it is possible to verify contents by technical means-for example by species testing or by other analysis of the physical or chemical characteristics of the product.

As a matter of normal commercial practice most winemakers already maintain the records they will be required by this Bill to keep. Where winemakers do not already maintain intake, production, sales and disposal records, the Corporation will assist them to establish simple and appropriate record keeping procedures. The Corporation will be providing a guide to wineries on the requirements of this Bill and will be visiting wineries to further explain the requirements of the label integrity program and to ensure that producers are familiar with the record-keeping requirements appropriate to their particular operations.

Labelling requirements concerning vintage, variety and region of origin are enshrined in food laws administered by State and Territory governments. This Bill does not change existing food laws or introduce new labelling requirements; nor does it encroach upon the authority and responsibilities of the States and Territories for administering those laws. In consultations, these governments have indicated that they would welcome the assistance of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation in monitoring compliance with wine labelling aspects of food laws. Evidence of any apparent breaches detected by the Corporation will be brought to the attention of the States and Territories for appropriate action, or action may be brought under the consumer deception provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

The wine industry does not seek through the label integrity program to emulate the European appellation system. There are no attempts to limit the types of grapes which can be grown in a specific region, to limit the yield which can be obtained from a vineyard or to prescribe certain methods of production. All that is required is that winemakers who make labelling claims of vintage, variety or region of origin, maintain the records necessary to substantiate the claims.

The Bill contains appropriate provisions necessary for effective administration of the program. These include standard provisions relating to the powers of inspectors, access to premises and the gathering of evidence of label offences.

The consequential amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 contained in part 2 of the Bill will maintain the existing arrangements concerning voting rights at annual general meetings of the Corporation, payment to the Corporation of levy money collected by the Commonwealth and refunds of any overpayments back to the Commonwealth.

The updated penalty rates specified in the schedule to the Bill relate to offences against provisions concerning the coverage of grape products, provision of information to the Corporation, export of grape products and offences against regulations made pursuant to the principal Act. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 which is now before the House contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Firstly, schedule one, operative on and from 1 January 1988, allows continued duty free treatment of ethyl hexanol. Schedule two operates on and from 1 July 1988 and provides a free rate of duty for rye grass seed and certain gasoline and other oils. This rate was previously applied by the Customs Tariff (Rates Alteration) Act 1988. Schedule three contains a minor amendment to subheading 9616.10 to align it with the international harmonised system. It will operate on and from 14 October 1988. Schedule four, operative on and from 1 March 1989, provides for the accelerated liberalisation of trade in textiles, clothing and footwear goods of New Zealand origin.

Schedule five, operative on and from 1 July 1989, contains further changes under the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (ANZCERTA) to remove tariff and quota restrictions on apparel from New Zealand and achieve free trade access a year earlier than originally proposed.

It also contains amendments to take account of changes in the names of a number of countries or places which qualify for preferential treatment. It includes amending to give effect to the Government's decision on the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries. These changes allow duty free entry to certain mining and agricultural equipment not normally made in Australia. In addition, schedule five includes a reduction in the rate of duty on soda ash to compensate for the effect of changes to the customs valuation system made on 1 July 1989. This reduction follows a report by the Industries Assistance Commission and subsequent discussions with the industries concerned.

Schedule six operates on and from 1 August 1989. It provides quota free and duty free access for certain ski boots and cross country ski footwear. It also implements a free rate of duty for certain fabric woven from PVC coated polyester, and woven cut corduroy. Schedules seven and eight contain amendments to correct industry assistance anomalies resulting from the introduction of the harmonised tariff. Schedule seven, operative on and from 12 October 1989, provides a free rate of duty for certain cast coated paper and paperboard. Schedule eight amendments will operate from seven days after this Bill receives royal assent. The goods covered in this schedule include machines for working metal, knives and cutting blades for woodchipping machines, plywood, sensitised papers and certain machines containing a computer controller.

Also contained in schedule eight are amendments to extend the provisions of the Australian System of Tariff Preferences (ASTP) to Poland and Hungary. Far-reaching reforms in the political and economic spheres are in train in both these countries. The Government attaches priority to the coordinated action being taken by Western industrialised countries to give support and encouragement to these changes. Our action is consistent with measures already adopted or being adopted in various other countries such as the United States of America, Japan and New Zealand. Finally, in schedule nine, which is to operate on and from 1 January 1990, is an amendment to item 19 in schedule four as a consequence of changes proposed by the Customs and Excise Legislation Bill (No. 4) 1989.
Financial Impact

The effect of the amendments to the textiles, clothing and footwear arrangements contained in this Bill are considered to be negligible. The revenue impact of changes to the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries is expected to be virtually nil as the equipment concerned is not manufactured in Australia in the normal course of business. The amendments relating to soda ash involve no Budget outlays.

Provision of ASTP status to Poland and Hungary can be expected to result in some increase in imports though this is unlikely to have any significant impact on domestic markets. Imports in 1988-89 were approximately $31m from Poland and $28m from Hungary. Customs revenue forgone as a result of the application of developing rates is expected to be approximately $1m in respect of Poland and $0.7m for Hungary.

It is difficult to assess the net financial impact of the proposed tariff changes to correct tariff anomalies. Some will have the effect of reducing or removing import duty; others will increase duty or permit reinstatement of bounty. However, the measures proposed will generally only restore the position which applied before 1 January 1988 and are not likely to result in any substantial change to revenue or outlays.
Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members.

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to incorporate into that Act an excise tariff proposal tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings and to effect a minor technical amendment to take account of the fact that the Australian Capital Territory has attained self-government.
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The excise duty for naturally occurring LPG is adjusted six-monthly on 1 April and 1 October each year in accordance with the Government's LPG excise policy announced in April 1980. The excise rate is calculated as 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne. The realised price is based on the weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sales of LPG during the immediately preceding six months. Under the petroleum excise arrangements introduced from 1 July 1987, LPG produced from onshore fields is exempt from excise, so the excise now applies only to offshore fields-that is, Bass Strait. No excise is payable on refinery-produced LPG.

Clause 4 of the Bill will amend the excise rate, with effect from 1 April 1989, from $6.25 a kilometre to a rate of free. The decrease reflects the fact that the excise threshold of $147 a tonne has not been reached on average over the immediately preceding six months.
Minor Technical Amendment

The opportunity has also been taken to effect a minor technical amendment to item 10 (a) of the schedule to the Act. This amendment concerns the treatment under the Act of government business enterprises established by the Australian Capital Territory Government now that the Territory has attained self-government and is explained in more detail in the explanatory memorandum.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The Government will not raise any revenue from excise on naturally occurring LPG for the six months from 1 April 1989. With a zero excise rate to apply from 1 April, total LPG excise receipts for the 1988-89 financial year are estimated at $11m compared with receipts of $19.8m in 1987-88.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1989[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I began to speak on this legislation prior to the luncheon break, the debate had developed into a wide ranging one. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) spoke before me. I said that he was a very decent fellow but that, unfortunately, his philosophical views did not necessarily coincide with those of the coalition. For that reason from time to time he runs into difficulties with his Party. In this country we hope to pursue a decent, necessary policy in respect of taxation revenue and in respect of expenditure. I commented that the document released last week by the Liberal and National parties, Economic Action Plan, mentions the looming crisis, and indeed there is great concern about our foreign debt situation and the structure of Australia's economy. I think that is a reasonable point for the Opposition to make in the document. However, we were disappointed with its response because it was puny. It talked about saving from expenditure, about cutting the unemployment benefit, in a rather spurious way, to a number of people who would be in need, about a number of other savings in areas such as education, Aboriginal affairs and foreign aid, and about spending that money in another way.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose one could debate the morality of the child-care rebate and its application and the subsidy for children. But the issue that really gives an indication as to where the Opposition is heading is that which relates to the tax on capital. Clearly, it is our concern that we need a decent taxation system which is fair to all. To seek to remove the tax on capital gains, which was introduced by this Government and is now an accepted part of the landscape, is a dishonest act. It is an act which perhaps will gain some political capital outside this place, but in terms of producing a fairer tax system, directing our taxation system towards a level playing field where everyone is treated equally, it is certainly a step backwards. It is very interesting to note the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review, and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed it out in Question Time today. The editorial as it relates to the Opposition's policy states:
By putting it on the agenda-
that is, the capital gains tax-

the Opposition has created a political issue by proposing a weak and philosophically unconvincing proposition. Its policy response, instead of showing some fiscal spine, lacks any philosophic coherence and will harm revenue.
My concern is that if one looks at a tax on capital gains--(Quorum formed)

Now that many of my colleagues are here in the House, perhaps they would like me to point out to all those who are listening, including those schoolchildren in the gallery, that the tactic of the Opposition is one of spoiling and destroying. Essentially, what we are hoping for and have tried to do over our time in government is to create a taxation system that is fair for all. The old adage in tax-and all accountants would know it-is income is income is income. If one gains income from selling a capital asset and one has to pay tax on the income, it is just the same as any income received from a dividend, interest, wages, rents or profits. It is a profit on the sale. One is not taxed on the nominal profit; one is taxed on the real profit. So it is a fair tax.

To suggest that those who have wealth should have the opportunity to make income without a tax liability as against those who do not have any wealth is absurd, unfair and preposterous. All on this side of the House understand that very well. Unfortunately for members of the Opposition, most of them understand it very well, too. They understand that it is not fair. It is not fair that a person can gain income in that way and not be taxed with a tax liability that might be as much as 47c in the dollar. That could become zero if the Leader of the Opposition were successful-God forbid-in becoming Prime Minister. People have to understand that.

Before we came to government the greatest growth industry in Australia was tax avoidance. Why was the tax avoidance industry flourishing? Why was everybody into bottom of the harbour schemes? Why was that possible during the 1970s and 1980s? It was possible because there was no capital gains tax. One was able to defer profits into capital, realise the capital gain and incur no tax liability. That is not a possibility that is open to anybody unless he happens to have considerable wealth. It is not possible for the pensioner in my electorate to have access to that sort of scheme. It is not possible for the person struggling to buy his own house. It is possible for those who deal in the share market in a very substantial way and for people who are wealthy to take advantage of that in a whole lot of ways.

What do we find in the Economic Action Plan? We find the abolition of capital gains tax and its replacement with a speculative gains tax, with a five-year phase-out resulting in a loss to revenue next year of $450m. Even accepting the Opposition's figures, that is a substantial amount. Again, the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review suggests that the total capital gains liability is about $25 billion. What is going to happen if the Opposition is successful in instituting this policy? We are going to find a mass of people rushing to realise their capital gains over a short period. An inefficiency in the taxation system will be created. There will be a distortion in investment that locks in those capital gains for the next six months. If the Opposition is successful, people will rush out and realise their capital gains and there will be a distortion of the way people plan their future because of the five-year phase-out time. This is not a system that in any way increases the equity of the taxation system. It is not a proposal that in any way increases the efficiency of the system. It creates a distortion. It opens up for all the friends of those on the other side opportunities for avoiding their taxation responsibilities.

The honourable member for Sturt is a decent fellow. During the debate I must have asked him half a dozen times, `What about this?'. He would not respond because he knows very clearly that this is unfair, that it is a rort. There will be a loss to revenue at a time when we are looking for fiscal restraint, at a time when the hairy-chested members of the Opposition are saying that there must be more substantial fiscal restraint, that we must cut down on expenditure. There are two ways in which a Budget surplus can be created. It can be created by increasing Budget revenue, by holding one's revenue base, or by cutting outlays. Indeed, as I said before, it was like waiting for Godot. As we know, Godot never came. We were waiting, waiting, waiting for the Opposition's fiscal response. We find that the Opposition's response said, `We will take $2.5m from here, give it back there, and there is no change to fiscal policy'. If there will be no change to fiscal policy under the policy of the Opposition, where is the adjustment going to lie? Is it going to be in interest rates, in monetary policy, or will it be in the area of wages? The suggestion is that the wages area is where the Opposition will make its mark.

As the Treasurer suggested yesterday, it is absurd to suggest that if enterprise bargaining is the way to go a group like the pilots will take the view, `There is a Liberal Government in Canberra. We will only ask for 5 per cent instead of 30 per cent'. Of course they will ask for 30 per cent. The position will be the same as it always has been with those opposite-appeasement, and the Opposition will pay it and it will flow through. Then where will the Opposition stand? That is what the Opposition has always done, and it knows it. How can the Opposition justify abolishing capital gains tax, which is eminently fair? How are capital gains any different from other income? It is eminently fair, and the Opposition knows it.

Other issues related to provisional tax are included in this legislation. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) mentioned the tear-jerking case of the widow in his electorate who only had $300,000 to invest. She had to pay provisional tax on her investment of $300,000. That was on top of her house and everything else she owned. Of course, the honourable member for Curtin comes from the leafy suburbs of Perth, where people have those sorts of substantial assets. I do not have any difficulty with her having to pay provisional tax. Provisional tax does not have to be paid for the first time in the year that the income is earned. There is a one-off impost, when the payment is substantial, but from then on it is a fair and reasonable way in which tax is levied. It means that people have to pay their share. Why is that a problem? In respect of provisional tax, we have increased the threshold so that fewer people have to make quarterly payments. We have made it easier and more efficient for them. Where is the difficulty? In respect of this legislation, there is no difficulty.

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill contains the Medicare levy amendment, which continues, until such time as there is a change, the 1.25 per cent levy on income. Within this legislation there are also some increases in the threshold at which one has to pay the levy. It sets in concrete the fact that we have said that we will not increase the levy and that the levy is an important part of our social program. The honourable member for Curtin said that we were being deceitful and dishonest and that we should say to people that the Medicare levy does not cover all the costs of providing health care. That is right; we have never denied that. That is the case. What is dishonest is the Opposition suggesting that it will put in place private health insurance which in some way will cover all that cost. All it will be doing is shifting from public expenditure into private expenditure, putting a requirement on people to take out private insurance, which will be much more substantial than the Medicare levy. Why did the Opposition not say when it was in government and we had a private health insurance scheme--

TALK.START.PARA: —Five of them.

—Five of them over seven years, just as we now have the fifth shadow Minister for community services and health in the six years of this Government. The Opposition cannot get its act together. Just as it had a health insurance scheme that included private health insurance, why did it never make it clear to people that that did not fully cover the costs of their health care? It was heavily subsidised. When a patient got a cheque from the Hospital Benefits Fund or whoever paid it to him, there was a significant subsidy in that from the government; there always has been. They are asking for more and more, and are being supported in their claim by the Opposition. If we are to be responsible about the way in which money is spent in this country, let us consider the way in which that expenditure occurs and let us be sensible about public funding. Let us not take the open cheque book approach, the approach that lets it go like crazy. There must be a considerable amount of fiscal restraint. One must restrain the way in which expenditure occurs. We have a history of doing that-a history of fairness-and that is what we stand for.
