We met with representatives of the National Farmers Federation at lunchtime today. They told us in no uncertain terms that the people of this nation are in for more shocks. If the balance of payments figure is not brought down, we will have to pay more taxation. That is what these Bills are all about-more taxes. Unfortunately, we hear that the wheat crop will be well down this year because of the dry weather, so we will not achieve the big income figure from that area that we expected. The wool market has fallen on its nose. The Australian Wool Corporation has nearly a million bales of wool in stock. The Chinese and the Russians have stopped buying wool. The amount of money we are receiving from beef sales is falling. The Americans are taking more of our beef market in Japan. The Koreans closed the market for a time. We are having greater difficulty in building our exports and balancing imports.

Of course, we continue to import because people are not encouraged to invest capital and thus create exports. I think it is an absolute nonsense that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that his Government would not introduce a capital gains tax. He told us that on national television two or three times, yet he turned around and introduced one. Although the family home was exempted, that is a distortion in the tax system. If one wants to argue about fairness in the tax system, as the honourable member for Perth did, one should take note of that distortion.

One of the Bills we are debating is the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has introduced a new pay as you earn system whereby companies with annual PAYE remittances exceeding $5m a year will be required to remit twice monthly tax instalment deductions made from wages and salaries. It is of no help to businesses to tell them that they must work out and submit twice monthly tax instalment deductions. They have enough to do, even on a yearly basis, without having to perform these tasks twice a month.

These measures were introduced to help the Treasurer to boost his surplus. It brings forward the collection of about half a billion dollars in PAYE tax from companies in this financial year. The whole Budget was toffied up by the Treasurer so that he could stand up in this House and announce a record surplus. His reason for doing so is beyond my imagination. I cannot see why we need the enormous surpluses that those on both sides of the House-the Opposition and the Government-are talking about. We are not in government yet, but we will be after the next election. I cannot see why we need these enormous surpluses. It just amounts to more taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you against public saving?

—It is all right if the funds are being used to pay off some of the debt that Government members have created. But they create a massive debt and then turn around and tax the people to death in order to pay it back. What sort of management of the economy is that? Some smaller companies are exempt from this change to the PAYE collections system. Large businesses will be penalised. As I mentioned, it is being introduced to increase the Government's surplus. The Government's stated objective is to reduce the frequency of PAYE remittances for small business. Obviously, small business welcomes this. However, the collection of tax has been made harder and harder, and companies are expected to submit collection quicker and quicker. We are practically paying it per day in order to keep the Treasury out of economic difficulties as it sucks in more and more revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 imposes rates of income tax payable by individuals and other tax units for the 1989-90 financial year. These are unfunded tax cuts. Hopefully, some tax reduction is involved in this amendment to the Income Tax Act. The third piece of legislation we are debating is the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989. The basic rate of Medicare levy continues to be 1.25 per cent of our total personal tax payments. It is interesting that one component of our medical well-being, the chemists, are meeting at Parliament House today to protest about the Government's iniquitous measures. The Government has made it more and more difficult for the chemists to operate. It has basically socialised the chemists and then turned around and put the screws on them, yet it wonders why they cannot perform and serve the public. Unfortunately, I notice that my doctor friend the honourable member for Perth has left the chamber. The Government has done the same thing to the medical profession. Members of that profession scream every now and again that they are not getting enough out of the system. I think the chemists have a good argument in their favour. It is up to the Government to continue to pay them a fair dispensing fee. In actual fact, they are agents of the Government. They dispense free medicine to the people. Many needy people rely on these medicines, although there is a lot of abuse of the system. I would like to think that the Government could clean up some of the abuses. I would like to take the chance to congratulate Mr Russell Cooper on his election as Premier of Queensland. He is the member for Roma, in my electorate. Queensland is the lowest taxing State in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can't talk.

—He can talk all right. It is amazing how business continues to go to Queensland because it is the lowest taxing State. Queensland was the first State to abolish death duties. The capital gains tax introduced by this Federal Government is only a form of death duty. As soon as people transfer capital from one person or company to another they will be taxed. It is a death duty in disguise. The National Party in Queensland was forward looking enough to abolish death duties. An enormous number of people still come up to Queensland to establish businesses and live, under the National Party Government.
—I thought they went up there to die.

—People go to Queensland to retire. Unfortunately, we all have to die somewhere. Most people go to the sunshine State to retire. Queensland exports for July-the latest figures I have-were valued at $793m, which was a slight fall. Queensland accounted for 19.8 per cent of Australia's exports in June. I wish to highlight the fact that those exports are all taxed, so they all add to the wealth of this nation. Our imports were $341m in the same month, which was down somewhat: Queensland accounts for 8.2 per cent of Australia's imports.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland is a developing State. Unfortunately, we have to pay some of these new taxes that have been imposed. The coalition's policy on abolishing the coal tax is very welcome, particularly in my electorate. This Government imposes $52m in tax on the open cut coalmines at Blackwater in my electorate. They are the only mines forced to pay this iniquitous tax. The Opposition's policy is to abolish that tax after the next election. I am sure that more companies will then be prepared to invest there. It is amazing how business, when restraints are taken away from them, are prepared to invest their money, to get on with the job and create some jobs.

The Government wants to stop mining and development. A company tried to get a goldmine going in Kakadu the other day and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) was the only bloke with enough guts to get up publicly and say that he supported it. I would like to support him 100 per cent. He is the only person on the Government's front bench with any commonsense at all when it comes to resource issues-or most issues, actually. At least he is prepared to get up and tell the people of this nation what he thinks should be done. There should be mining there. The mine in question is not even in Kakadu National Park. A lot of nonsense is written in the newspapers about mining in the park. This mine is not in the park; it was never in the park. It should be developed.

We had an announcement today that Australia's balance of payments deficit is $1.7 billion-that is debt, not credit. Yet this Government sits back and makes a green announcement, just prior to the election, about not being able to create another mine. This is like the uranium mine policy: it is a disaster for the nation. Slowly but surely, we are daily going bankrupt. We should encourage miners from around the world to come here and use our resources. Areas like Kakadu can be mined and rehabilitated. I worked there years ago. There are lumps of minerals all over the place. There are outcrops of mineral all over the Kakadu area. If someone knocked half a dozen off we would not even know they had gone. But here is a potential mine with $1 billion worth of natural resources in it. We are desperate for income to improve the balance of payments and we have to slug the Australian people through new taxation Bills because we are not able to mine and develop these resources.

We cannot have it both ways. We hand out $20 billion or $30 billion in social security payments. To do all that we have to earn some income. We have to earn some wealth first in order to do that. I strongly support the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for his stance on mining in the Northern Territory. It is the best thing I have heard from a Minister of this Government for a long time. Those on this side of the House give him full support, and I am sure the Australian people do too. We have long gone past the day where we can selectively decide not to mine here or develop there. We have to develop sensibly. There is no reason why that cannot be done.

Queensland is one of the leading tourist States. Tourism is helping our balance of payments and it is keeping our taxation down by earning overseas revenue, which helps us lift our standard of living-or at least hold it. Under this Government our standard of living has fallen continually, as the figures tell us. We have a fantastic tourist industry, built up over a number of years, which has been encouraged by the abolition of death duties and capital gains taxes in Queensland under Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen and the very good National Party Government in that State. We have seen a boom in tourism, with $5 billion being invested last year. What do we see now? We see an airline strike sponsored by this Government. It is an absolute disgrace. We are being told now that the airlines will not be back in the air until some time after Easter next year. It is an absolute abomination. The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), who is at the table, should know. He should tell me when the pilots will go back to work. He is a member of the Government. He is the tourism Minister. He should tell me.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—When the pilots are going back to work.

—No, we do not have to encourage them. We are not involved at all. It is up to the Government to get people working. We cannot afford this nonsense where we have the whole of the airline industry tied up doing nothing. The Minister is an absolute disgrace.
—It is destroying Cairns and Townsville.

—Townsville! People cannot even get to Queensland. The only way us politicians have been able to get up there in the last three months is in a Royal Australian Air Force plane or on a VIP flight. As an Australian, I am absolutely ashamed of this Government and the airline companies and I am starting to be ashamed of the pilots. We cannot afford--

—To continue this ridiculous tie-up.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I agree with your sentiments, but it is all to do with taxation and balance of payments. We are speaking today on the new taxation Bills that have been introduced. The debate is all to do with the Government needing more tax funds because it is not prepared to mine or to have the airline industry and business operating. SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to focus on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. In particular, I want to look at the current debate, which I am sure will continue when my friend and colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) announces the Opposition's health policy for the next election. The debate has been raging in Australia for quite some time, and I would like to pick up some of the main points as I see them. The people who talk about private insurance always have in the back of their minds-even though they may not say it-that the private sector can do many things more efficiently than the public sector. In many cases I would agree. There is no doubt about that. In any market oriented delivery of services or goods I think the private sector is more efficient. But we must understand that health insurance is not one of those industries, if I can call it that, that are private enterprise industries. When one considers health insurance vis-a-vis the rest of the private sector, two major characteristics are lacking. The first, of course, is that private health insurance funds have never been able to make a profit. In fact, it is written into the legislation that they cannot make a profit. The profit motive is just not there. A profit is not permitted to be made. The second thing, of course, is something called the community rating principle, which really means that a health insurance fund, in its charges, cannot differentiate between the users of the service. That is, the same amount is charged to someone who is fit, healthy and young as is charged to someone who is old and who uses those services quite a bit. It can be seen that those two characteristics in particular make health insurance different from the private sector-very much different. Because it is so heavily regulated in those terms, it cannot be compared with the rest of the private sector.

From there one goes to the efficiency of health insurance. When the efficiency of health insurance is being considered, the distinction really has to be made between health insurance and health delivery. I am not talking about the delivery of health services, although I will refer to that later. I am now talking about the efficiency of the health insurance system. The purpose of health insurance, of course, is to share the risks-that is, to pool resources and share the risks that we all face: at some time or other we might have to undergo medical treatment. I suggest to the House that the way in which the efficiency of health insurance is measured is to look at how much of that insurance money goes to paying medical bills.

It seems self-evident to me that the less that is spent on administration, the more efficient health insurance is. For example, under the Canadian Medicare scheme, 2c of every dollar is spent on administration. In Australia, Medicare spends 4c of every dollar on administration. The private insurance systems, when they existed, were spending 14c of every dollar. They are not my figures or the Government's figures; they are from the Consumer Health Forum. It can be seen that at present Medicare spends 4c in every dollar compared with 14c in every dollar that was spent by the private funds. In terms of getting the insurance dollar to where it is supposed to be, that is very much more efficient in terms of paying medical bills. However, one cannot insure if the costs are unknown. The simple fact is-I will return to this a little later-that health insurance in Australia, under any system, private or public, has never been comprehensive enough to pay the doctor's bill. All it has ever done is got within spitting distance, really, of some doctors' bills, and never got anywhere near some others.

This legislation also recommits the Government to collecting 1.25c of Medicare levy. That has not increased, but in terms of paying, in terms of the cost of health insurance for Australians, it can be seen that it is very equitable in that the more money a person earns, the more money he pays. It is very progressive in that way. People on low incomes are exempted altogether. The cost of health insurance is not a burden on the Australian people.

One of the health insurance matters that really should be considered is accessibility. Studies show that the Canadian experience is that where charges in excess of the schedule fee occur, accessibility, particularly for people on low incomes, is very much inhibited. Charging more than the schedule fee really means that people on low incomes do not have equal access to many of those services. One needs to look at some examples to really appreciate just what happens when significant charges over and above the schedule fee are made. I have a couple of examples here. The first relates to item No. 514, for which the schedule fee is $74. The anaesthetist charged $135, or 182 per cent above the schedule fee. How would a person feel if he had a rather major operation such as heart surgery for which the schedule fee was $745 and he received a bill for $2,000, which is $1,300 over and above the schedule fee? The person would not be feeling too good when he got out of hospital-not from a financial point of view; I would hope that the operation was a success. That represents a charge which is a massive 268 per cent above the schedule fee.

The point I am making is that there is absolutely no restriction on what can be charged-usually by specialists; I am not having a go at general practitioners, because by and large they are the people who are sticking to the schedule fee and are bulk billing. Another example relates to item No. 8598, rhinoplasty. The schedule fee was $555. The charge was $2,000, which is 360 per cent above the schedule fee. I will not continue with that, but I think that serves to illustrate that when specialists charge above the schedule fee to the extent that they have, they not only impose a very significant financial burden on their patients but also knock back accessibility, because no-one on low income could afford to pay over and above the schedule fee. It is not as though Medicare underinsures.

By way of example, I will detail Medicare-only incomes for selected occupations; that is, only what Medicare pays. These specialists can obtain income from four to five other areas. An obstetrician received $219,000 from Medicare; a dermatologist, $231,000; an anaesthetist, $118,000; a plastic surgeon-the one who charged $2,000 for a $555 operation-$210,000; an ophthalmologist, $244,000. If the House looks at those amounts, it will see that those specialists are not underpaid. I have to say that those figures are gross figures and that the costs of running the practices have to come out of them. However, at a minimum, $30,000 could be added to most of those incomes, even if they never exceeded the schedule fee. Medicare does not underinsure, but certain specialists overcharge.

Quite recently we heard the old re-run about long waiting lists. I point out to the House the efficiency of our hospitals. The issue of long waiting lists is one of those things that are trumped up by some doctors in particular to try to make out that Medicare is failing. When the efficiency of our hospitals is considered, it will be seen that 3 1/2 million Australians go through our hospitals every year-the highest per capita number in the world. Per capita, there are more Australians in hospital than any other race on the face of the earth. It is a staggering 218 out of every 1,000. It is not public servants or politicians who put people into hospitals; it is the medical profession itself. There are more private hospital beds now than ever before. If there are long waiting lists and if private enterprise is being considered, it seems to me that, if private enterprise was working efficiently, it would move in and say, `We will provide those beds and we will do it at a cost which is less than what the public sector can do it for.' But private enterprise does not do that. The question that really has to be asked is: How efficient is the private sector? It seems to me that, in an instance such as that, it is not being very efficient at all, because certainly, if it was good enough, it would take up the slack.

I am concerned also about an article which contained comments by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Tangney in last Saturday's West Australian. The article is headed, `Hospital Crisis Claimed'. I am not all that worried about what the shadow Minister has to say, but Dr Jones, the Western Australian President of the Australian Medical Association (AMA), said this:
The swing away from private insurance is putting massive pressure on public hospitals.

Let us have a look at waiting lists. If honourable members really want to have a look at the AMA's role in waiting lists, they have only to look at the Sun-Herald of 16 October last year, which carried an article about the rebel surgeons, as they were called, who went back into the public system under the $12m that the Greiner Government gave them. The article states:
The return of the rebel surgeons-who quit the public hospitals in the 1984 doctors' strike-is aimed at reducing the hospital waiting list of 40,000.
Health Department secretary Michael Rosser predicted the waiting list would be cut by 10,000 within a year of the surgeons' return.

One really has to ask oneself whether the AMA is all that concerned about waiting lists when it can go on strike in the way that it has, and the Health Department secretary reckons that the waiting list can be slashed by 10,000 because these blokes have gone back to work. I raise that as background to this argument about waiting lists. Of course, it is a complete furphy because, as I have said before, we have never shifted more people through our hospitals than are being shifted now. It amounts to some 3.5 million Australians every year.

I am sure that when Dr Jones talks about the number of people who are eligible for private insurance he knows that in Western Australia, in December 1983, 443,000 people, representing 32.3 per cent of Western Australians, had private hospital insurance. That was before Medicare was introduced. The latest figure shows that 621,000, or 39.2 per cent of people in Western Australia, now have private hospital coverage. We have seen a massive increase in the number of people who can go to a private hospital because they have insurance.

What we have to consider in this whole debate, when we throw up figures about the number of people with private insurance, is the number of people who can go to a private hospital because they have insurance. The figures, which have been supplied by the Health Insurance Commission, are accurate. The best thing one can say about Dr Jones's comments is that they are scaremongering. The worst thing one can say about them is that he is lying. It is simply not true that waiting lists in Western Australia or in any other State are due to the lack of people having private insurance. The facts do not support the argument. At present more people in Australia have private hospital coverage than was the case before Medicare was introduced.

Why do so many people who are privately insured go into public hospitals? I have been told that 46 per cent of people in public hospitals are privately insured. Although they could go into a private hospital they choose to go into a public hospital. According to the literature that is about nowadays, many people do so because they have more faith in public hospitals, because public hospitals are better resourced. I know that a significant number of doctors would rather work in the private hospital system.

Subsequent to my appearance on a show on 6PR in Perth last week I received a phone call to the effect that Dr Jones-I do not know whether this is true, but I would like him to refute it, if he can-has a vested interest in private hospitals because he is a director of the Markalinga hospital chain, one of the three biggest in Australia. I am told that it owns the Mount Hospital. There is nothing wrong with that. I do not criticise him for being a director of a private hospital. However, if he takes part in public debate he should make that fact known. Vested interests should be known by people listening to the argument. As I have said, the facts do not support his argument.

When one compares private health insurance with public health insurance one should look at a country that has a private health insurance system, such as the United States of America. One should compare such a country with Australia which at present has a public system. Currently the United States spends just under 12 per cent of its gross domestic product on its health system. Australia spends 7 1/2 per cent. If Australia were to spend at the same rate as America does we would spend $15 billion more on health care than we do. I am not saying that any private system in Australia has ever spent at that rate, but it makes an interesting comparison when one looks at private insurance versus public insurance. I know, from articles that I have read and from what people have told me, that if any country is looking around to see whether it can improve its health insurance system, it is America. The Americans are looking very closely at the Canadian system. Senator Eddie Kennedy is leading the charge in his State to try to move to a public system. As I said at the outset, when one considers health insurance one should look at a system which cuts down on the cost of administration. It has been proved in Australia and in Canada that in terms of medical insurance public systems are much more efficient than private systems.

Another thing with private systems-and we have had a number in this country-is that not everyone is insured. Also, everybody pays the same rate. Therefore, people on low incomes are very much at a disadvantage compared with those on high incomes. I do not think that even my friend from Tangney would look at the AMA's medicover proposal. It is really medimadness. Who could sell such a proposal? One of the features of the proposal, which was floated quite recently but then dropped out of sight-I have not heard about it since and I do not think we will hear about it again-was that the system would be compulsory and privately run. People would have to be in it, but it would be run by private organisations. Another feature was that each organisation had to charge the same rate. So even if one believes that there may be some efficiencies in private health insurance, the AMA's stipulation was that efficiencies in one organisation cannot be passed on to those who pay the insurance; that is out. Private systems suffer from that restriction on the way they are run when compared with other privately run organisations in the economy. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), I intend to confine my remarks in this cognate debate to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. I recorded the fact that twice in his contribution the honourable member referred to me across the chamber as his friend and colleague. I accept that greeting in the sense that it was meant. It was more than just parliamentary jargon because, outside of party lines, we are friends and, in a broader sense, colleagues. My honourable friend likes me so much that he lives in the middle of my electorate-in fact, within walking distance of my electorate office which is miles away from the people he purports to represent.
—I bet he does not vote for you.

—Nevertheless, he is welcome to stay on as a resident, if not as a person on the electoral roll because, as the honourable member for Dunkley said, he is unlikely to vote for me. I respond to his contribution by joining him in debate on this issue. I recognise the long interest that he has held in health policy matters and the particular regard and attention that he has paid to issues and debates in the general health portfolio. Cryptically, he is known in the health portfolio as the doctors' friend.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the only problems I can identify in terms of the honourable member for Canning is that he has an ideological bent against one of the helping and caring professions of the country. He wastes a lot of his time, like his colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), in the popular sport, at least on Labor Party benches, of doctor bashing. It is matched only by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who has now invented a new sport of pharmacy bashing. But I leave that to one side. I hope that the honourable member is not going to leave the chamber, because I would like him to hear some of the points I want to make in response to his arguments about the efficiency of the health insurance industry, the number of people who are privately insured and the United States of America health model.

We have the opportunity to debate the Bill only because of the Opposition's success when we were considering the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987. At that time the Government attempted to legislate for automatic increases in the Medicare levy which would have taken this Bill off the parliamentary agenda on an annual basis. Thankfully, the Australian Democrats supported the Opposition in the Senate, and we have put the Government in the proper position of having to relegislate on an annual basis for the levy. The Government has done that, and we do not oppose the Bill or the Government relegislating for the 1.25 per cent Medicare levy or the amendments that will change the income levels under which that levy impacts. When we come to the order of the day arising out of the cognate debate, I will move a second reading amendment in relation to the Bill, and my contribution is predicated on the moving of that amendment. I will move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) expresses its concern that despite its increasing cost Medicare is delivering a lower level of health care, particularly to the poor and needy;
(2) condemns changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will rob the community of high quality pharmaceutical services;
(3) calls upon the Government to ensure that all Australians receive the high quality, affordable health care to which they are entitled'.
Having foreshadowed that I will be moving that second reading amendment, I return to the first point which is that this House:
(1) expresses its concern that despite its increasing cost Medicare is delivering a lower level of health care, particularly to the poor and the needy;

I refer to the cost because since the Government has been in power there has been a veritable cost explosion. In 1983-84, the year prior to the introduction of Medicare-I draw all figures from the relevant Budget Papers-the Commonwealth's total outlays on health were $4.3 billion. In the year that Medicare was introduced, that jumped to $6.1 billion, and we have now arrived at the position where in the last Budget we are spending just short of $11.8 billion. This explosion of costs cannot be explained away, or even understood, by the increase of the Australian population.

If I can convert the explosion of costs into percentages, in 1982-83 we were spending 6.9 per cent of total Budget outlays through the health portfolio and, now that we are spending just short of $11.8 billion dollars, that has jumped dramatically to 13.6 per cent of total government outlays. As I am the shadow Minister for health, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know that I have had several opportunities, and I will continue to have opportunities, to talk about Medicare and its deficiencies.

In earlier speeches I have talked about the financial unsustainability of Medicare. Without repeating all of the contributions I have made, I reiterate one rhetorical question. For that amount of money, we expect that we would have the best, you beaut, bolted down, shut tight, health system one could ever hope to find. The sad reality is that we do not. We are spending $11.8 billion of taxpayers' money-because that is what it is; the Government does not have any money of its own; it can spend only what it raises by taxes or borrowings, and borrowings in turn have to be repaid by taxes-and one would think we would have the best system known to man or woman. Regrettably, we have far from it.

The single biggest indicator of the deficiencies of the current health system, presided over as it is by Medicare, is public hospital waiting lists. People in the health care professions-health care administrators and State government officials-reliably and conservatively state that approximately 100,000 people around the country are now languishing on public hospital waiting lists awaiting surgery of one kind or another. We are told that it is elective surgery, it is not life threatening surgery, so they can wait for it, and obviously there will never always be a bed for everyone who wants one just when he wants it. To tell aged people that a hip replacement, upon which they are totally dependent for their mobility, is something that they can wait for, is not something that I would be prepared to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you do something about the--

—Before I get another contribution from the honourable member for Phillip-I understand her anxiety to maximise her speaking opportunities in this place by interjecting during my contribution, because after the next election she will not be here-I invite her to keep quiet while I continue my remarks. I would not want to tell someone that a hip replacement was something that he could wait for, and certainly I do not want to live in a society that says, `Just languish and wait in the queue, in an immobile state, until we come up with a public hospital bed for you'.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not want to tell aged people who are waiting for cataract operations, upon which their sight is totally dependent, to wait in the queue. I would not want to tell the parents of a young person injured in a road accident that that person will have to languish in the casualty department, or perhaps we could ring around to see whether another hospital could fit that person in. That is the reality in Australia.

The honourable member for Canning said, as he always does when we identify deficiencies in the system-he did not dispute that this was not the case-that it was the doctors' fault. I have news for him. I spend almost all of my non-parliamentary time visiting health care sites and public and private hospitals around the country. The reason I speak with such gravity and confidence on this point is that the people who are in the front of the queue telling me about this waiting list problem are not doctors but public hospital administrators, who have to preside over this crisis, and they simply do not know what to do because the beds are not available. That is the first point.

The second point is that public hospital waiting lists are an example that we do not have the best system possible. Because the Government has been faced with a cost blow-out, and throughout its entire period of office has been ideologically unwilling to face up to that central core cost blow-out due to Medicare, it has been trying to curb and curtail costs at the margin. That is why, in almost every Budget or economic statement, we get changes to the medical benefits schedule, whether it is to cut back on pathology, as it did in 1986, to cut back on a whole series of items, as it did in the May mini-Budget in 1987, to constantly attack doctors' incomes, or-to bring us right up to date-to try to save money on the pharmaceuticals benefits scheme.

The reason for the second part of our proposed amendment, which condemns the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, in a debate during which we are talking about Medicare, is that the two issues are intimately related. Because the Government is unwilling ideologically and politically to face up to the central core problem, it is desperately trying to curtail costs at the margin and to pick any identifiable area in the health portfolio where it can save money. For the Government to admit that there is anything wrong with the public hospital system or with Medicare would be to admit that the Government got it wrong during its period of office. The Government is not prepared to make that admission late in its electoral cycle.

Medicare is terrific for many people as long as they do not get sick and, importantly, as long as they do not require a public hospital bed. The honourable member for Canning, during his contribution, ignoring all of the deficiencies of Medicare, made the point that we have to stay with a public health insurance system because it is far more efficient and because public health insurance systems spend far less of their moneys on administration and, therefore, are more efficient. It is true that public health insurance systems spend less on administration than do private health funds. However, if I were the administrator of a private health fund, if I had compulsory contributions from the entire Australian community, if I did not have to advertise to get contributors and if I did not have to go out into the marketplace to compete against other health funds that were also advertising for contributors, I could save a hell of a lot of money too on my administration costs.

If the compulsory income tax arrangements under which the Medicare levy is garnisheed from the Australian community were removed and if compulsory income tax from which the majority of health expenditure derives were removed-despite what honourable members might think or hope, the Medicare levy has never fully funded the system. I can recall that back in 1984, we were promised that the Medicare levy, which was then one per cent, would largely fund the system; but it never did. Although the Medicare levy is now at 1.25 per cent, it raises only 22 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays on health. The majority, 78 per cent, comes out of general consolidated revenue that is paid for by our taxes.

I hope that the honourable member for Canning is in his office listening to me. The point that I am making in response to his contribution is that he does not recognise the absolute rolled gold competitive advantage that Medicare has because of its compulsory contributor base and the fact that it does not, in any administrative sense, have to go out and collect the money. The Australian Taxation Office does that for it. I could put aside my ideological perspective on health and say, `Yes, let us have a totally public system', if I could be guaranteed that a totally public system would meet all the needs. However, it already falls far short of the community's needs. The cruellist irony is that the people whom a public health insurance system should be looking after, namely, the aged and the disadvantaged, are the very people who are being pushed further and further to the end of those public hospital waiting lists.

The whole problem relates to the drop-out rate or the lack of uptake of private health insurance. The honourable member for Canning, for whom I have affection and respect, really is asking us to read too much into what he says when he simply cites gross numbers of people who have private insurance in this country. For the country's sake, I hope that, as our population grows, there will be more people than before. Even year 2 students can understand that if there are more people, there are more people. I hope also that, if there are more people, more people will be privately insured than there were before.

A consideration of the percentages of people who are privately insured reveals a completely different understanding of the problem. Prior to the introduction of Medicare, 61.5 per cent of the population was privately insured. That figure is now just above 45 per cent of the population. Therein lies the root of the problem. Medicare as we know it is unsustainable. Even with the money that we now spend, we cannot meet all of the demands and needs in the community. Because the Government cannot keep pace with the outlays that are required, it is desperately trying to save money. There will never be enough public moneys. The whole imbalance in the health-care system is the big drop in the numbers of people who are privately insured.

The Liberal Party has not approached this problem from some ideological binge from the Right. People such as the honourable member for Canning and those who populate organisations such as the Consumer Health Forum of Australia raise the great bogey of the American health system. Perhaps the private doctors association might hanker for an American type environment, but the Liberal and National parties certainly do not. We have never, ever talked about tearing about Medicare and going to a totally private, risk-rated system in which large percentages of the population are underinsured.

Members of the Liberal and National parties may be many things, but we are not slow learners. One of the things that the Liberal Party has learnt from Medibank and Medicare is that never again in this country must we ever allow people to be uninsured, as occurred during the Liberal Party's last period of government. It made a mistake on that point. Never again should we allow people to be underinsured, as occurred during the Liberal Party's last period in government. However, if the Government believes that it is possible to have a totally public health-care system with people continually dropping out of private health insurance, it must think again. The Medicare system is sending the country broke and is delivering a lesser quality of service.

What is the solution? It is staring us in the face. It is simply to return to a better balance between public and private health insurance. It is not to tear up Medicare or to run off and try to graft the American model onto the Australian system. Indeed, it is not to look at any international example. The solution is to return to what used to work well in this country, but with the improvements that I have mentioned, namely, everybody being insured at a comprehensive level for both medical and hospital treatment. That is the thrust of Liberal Party policy, which is well known and will be taken to the next election. The Liberal Party will retain and improve Medicare. At the end of the day, Medicare will focus on the aged and disadvantaged, who are the very people who should be looked after at a better level than they are being looked after at the moment. For the rest of Australians-and I include you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and me in that-they will be encouraged to go back to private health insurance or to stay in private health insurance with the assistance of a taxation rebate. If that sensible, balanced policy is implemented, the right mix between publicly and privately funding the system will be achieved, together with the third point of this proposed amendment. All Australians will receive high quality, affordable health care to which they are entitled.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOAT FIBRE LEVY BILL 1989[COGNATE BILL:GOAT FIBRE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—It was good of you to turn up; what a pity you could not be here on time.

—I suppose it is appropriate, after those comments, that I now refer to the Goat Fibre Levy Bill 1989 and the Goat Fibre Levy Collection Bill 1989. I commend this legislation and those involved in the goat fibre industry in Australia. The purpose of these Bills, which result from an initiative of those people, is to introduce a levy, to be collected on the sale of goat fibre, for research to assist the development of the industry. It was two years ago that the industry first made the request. The industry comprises three sectors: the mohair, cashmere and cashgora sectors. The industry is growing quickly and has the potential to be a major agricultural and export industry for Australia within the foreseeable future. At present, the export sales amount to about $10m and this will rapidly increase over the years ahead. In addition to the income from the fibre there is the income from goat meat and hides, and there is an industry in the export of live goats.

SPEECH.PARA: The goat industry in the broader term-the keeping of goats for fibre or for meat-has a valuable role to play in the land management of this country because goats are very capable grazers of pasture to which other forms of livestock, sheep and cattle, may not be so attracted. This includes a number of weeds and other less desirable species of plants. So there is a very valuable role for this animal and for this industry.

The industry has recognised that it needs to improve the quality of the fibre. Therefore, this legislation introduces a levy of 1 1/2 per cent to be paid on the gross value of sales of goat fibre to commence on 1 January next year, and a maximum of 5 per cent is allowed for in the legislation. The Federal Government, under its rural research arrangements, will match that levy on a dollar for dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of the industry, as it matches the levies of other primary industries. Initially, the industry levy is expected to raise $150,000 in a full year, with an additional $50,000 from the Commonwealth Government.

In particular, the goat fibre industry organisations, such as the Angora Mohair Breeders Association, are to be commended on the scale of the levy that they have requested. Because the figure I cited of $150,000 is not a huge amount at this stage, it disguises the very significant percentage of the value of production that the industry is prepared to commit of its own income. It is probably the highest in percentage terms, or matches the highest, of any of the 19 or 20 other agricultural industries that are presently involved in these cooperative dollar for dollar research arrangements with the Government. In total levy terms it would rank with wool and meat-at the top of what any rural industry is prepared to commit. The Government target for rural industry is 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. The goat fibre industry from day one will be committing three times the maximum that the Government is using as the target for other agricultural industries. A number of these agricultural industries are on only 0.2 per cent or 0.3 per cent of the gross value of production. So that indicates the commitment by the industry. I am advised that, in addition, the industry will be imposing a voluntary levy of 2 per cent of the value of sales for promotion. At least, that is the case for the angora breeders for angora mohair. So there is this very significant contribution by the industry.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has looked at this legislation, as it looks at other legislation, and it has made a number of recommendations critical of the legislation. One recommendation, which perhaps does not sound very serious, is the question of the definition of a goat's fibre-selling broker. The Senate Committee noted that the definition in the legislation refers to a `goat's fibre-selling broker' and that the provision should be drafted so as not to contemplate a goat authorising a broker to sell its own fibre! So perhaps the drafters of this legislation should take into account that although acknowledging that the goat is a very intelligent animal, a goat is probably not quite up to determining its own broker for the selling of its fibre. The Senate may wish to look at that when this legislation reaches the Senate.

On a more serious note, I refer to another point that the Senate Committee makes in relation to subclause 3 (1) of the Goat Fibre Levy Collection Bill, which is the definition of `magistrate' to include justice of the peace. I quote from the Committee report:

The definition of magistrate in the Bill includes a `justice of the peace', who is enabled to issue a warrant for an authorised person to enter premises pursuant to the provision of clause 12 of the legislation. The Committee does not accept that a justice of the peace should be enabled to issue a search warrant. The view of the Committee is that justices of the peace are not judicial officers, and that the issue of search warrants should be confined to judicial officers.
The provision is brought to the attention of the Senate in that it may breach principle 1 (a) (i) and trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

I draw the attention of the Government to the recommendations of the Senate Committee. The Opposition, in supporting this legislation, will not be moving any of the amendments which may be considered appropriate by that Senate Committee. But if the Government does not answer those comments made by the Senate Committee and comply with them where appropriate with amendments, either here or in the Senate, then the coalition parties will have to consider pursuing amendments in the Senate. I say that in a constructive way. If there is an adequate explanation as to why there is no need to accept any of those Senate Committee recommendations, then it is important for it to be put forward so that we in the Opposition can allow the legislation through the Senate without moving amendments. I will be interested to hear the definition of a goat's fibre-selling broker.

I also refer to the plans of the angora mohair breeders for developing their section of the total industry as quickly as possible. Australian mohair production is about 900,000 kilograms a year. That is about 4 per cent or 5 per cent of world production. South Africa is the world's leading producer with about 45 per cent of total production. South Africa's fibre quality is also the best. Australian mohair, or angora goat fibre, suffers from kemp and its fleece weight is under half that of South Africa's. Therefore, the development of the genetic excellence of our goats' fibre is a long way behind that of South Africa.

If we are restricted in Australia to improving on the genetic material of the animals that we have here now, this improvement will take 30 to 40 years. The best way to improve any livestock breed, whether it is sheep, cattle or goats, is to obtain the best genetic material available in the world, either by importing live animals or, where for disease reasons or other reasons that is not practical, by semen or embryos. The best way to develop the potential of this important industry is by obtaining the best genetic material that is available so that it becomes a major export industry in the future. Therefore, this industry wants to-and correctly wants to-import genetic material from South Africa. It has only been possible to import any genetic material from South Africa since June of this year, when South Africa removed the embargo that it had in place on export of these goats. This follows the Zimbabwe tactic, as I would call it, which happened recently, in which there was some South African material smuggled out through Zimbabwe, and it is now being developed for the future benefit of the industry in New Zealand and Australia.

The Angora Mohair Breeders Association has formed a company to legally and openly import 100 embryos from South Africa, as they are now available, which will eventually result in about 6,000 genetically superior pure bred goats being distributed through the national flock. The Association believes that there is no future in trying to repeat the Zimbabwe tactic or to import from Zimbabwe because of the quality of the inferior goats. There are also other disease problems.

Coincidentally, our maximum security quarantine station on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands will have space available in 1991, which would allow the implanting of those embryos into parent stock and the upgrading of the breed using this superior genetic material to begin. If the Angora Mohair Breeders Association is not able to obtain approval in the near future for those embryos from South Africa, I am advised that there will be no space on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands for another two or three years.

There is a problem, in that the Federal Government has restrictions on trade with South Africa. I hope that the Government takes a sensible approach to determining this application, because we are not talking about significant and ongoing trade with South Africa. We are talking about trade worth several million dollars in a one-off operation. The trade would not advantage South Africa to any great degree, but it would dramatically advantage Australia by assisting this very important industry. Australia has the ability to become the world's leading producer and exporter of goat fibre. I notice that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) is at the table. I sincerely suggest to him that the goat fibre industry must be one of the most important sunrise industries in this country. It could earn Australia not just millions of dollars but hundreds of millions of dollars each year through the export of goat fibre. Australia has the right climate and the right amount of area. It has appropriate management skills-there are related skills in sheep and goat husbandry-to ensure a successful industry.

In concluding my remarks I indicate again the Opposition's support for the legislation. A coalition government is in favour of allowing Angora Mohair Breeders of Australia Ltd to import embryos from South Africa. I hope that commonsense prevails and that this Government approves that application in order to guarantee the maximum development of this most important industry.

The goat fibre industry, as the shadow Minister said, comprises mohair, cashmere and cashgore fibre production. In my electorate there is another breed-the only ones in Australia-which produces another form of animal fibre, the South American alpaca. The Halpin family, Geoff and his wife, now have a small breeding stock of alpacas on their farm at Seymour. The alpaca is not part of the goat family; it is a member of the camelidae family. It produces about a 28 micron wool which is very similar to angora in its softness. It produces a very soft and beautiful fibre. I hope that this small herd, this initial breeding stock that the Halpins have managed to import, mostly from the United States, represents the commencement of yet another successful Australian animal fibre industry.

The goat fibre industry in this country began at the turn of the century when there was considerable interest in the angora goat for mohair production. Unfortunately, after the industry's commencement in this country, the price of mohair fell and many of the herds were dispersed or simply released into the wild. This country has many problems with feral animals, and those original angora herds formed the basis of the large herds of feral goats in Australia. Anyone from the western plains of New South Wales-for example, in the Paroo country, in the Murrumbidgee valley areas-will be aware that there are enormous numbers of feral goats causing great damage to agriculture. Those goats are rapidly being trapped because there is now a major market for goat meat. Many of those feral goats form the basis of a valuable goat meat exporting business. They are now being trapped, grain fed, fattened up and exported. It is still a pity that those goats are feral. The damage that they do is irreparable. We will never get rid of all of them from our outback areas. We will always have a feral goat problem.

In the 1970s interest in goat fibre again rose with the expansion of the angora goat population. During the 1980s the cashmere industry has developed. One positive aspect of the development of this industry is that goats can be used to complement the grazing of sheep and cattle. In regard to whole farm planning, one can now have a mixture of sheep and goats in mixed grazing areas, which improves the utilisation of pasture. The goats can be used to control weeds, thus reducing the need for costly chemicals. The use of goats has the added advantage of avoiding chemical pollution and toxicity problems. This is one of the exciting things about the goat fibre industry. Because so many farmers have adopted whole planned management systems, one can now integrate in a mixed grazing area a variety of fibre producing animals which will complement each other, assist with environmental controls and reduce the amount of toxic chemicals and other herbicides that farmers need to use to control noxious weeds introduced by Europeans into this country.

It is frightening to think about the damage caused by white people to this country and its effect on our agricultural productivity. In my electorate most of the noxious weed problems relate to introduced species. The Cape broom is being found in parts of my electorate. It is in bloom now. If one drives around the hill areas of my electorate one sees the Cape broom flowering everywhere. It is starting to become devastating in Victoria. I wonder about the irresponsibility of our forefathers, and that of some people today. Recently, I travelled through a wilderness area in Thailand-although there is not much wilderness area left. An Australian tourist in our group reached out, pulled up some plants and put them in a bag. As I thought she wanted to take them back to Australia, I made myself known to her and suggested that if I saw her at the airport I would advise the Australian Customs Service of what she was up to and ensure that she was properly punished for trying to introduce yet another unknown plant species into Australia, with the attendant quarantine risks. I wonder how many Australians really understand when they travel overseas the potential damage they can cause our major export earners, our rural sector, by taking a very careless approach to introducing foreign plants and untested plants in quarantine areas in Australia.

I have strayed from the main aspects of the Bill. The industry has expanded very rapidly in the 1970s and 1980s. As the shadow Minister said, whilst Australia produces only 6 per cent of the world's mohair and less than one per cent of the world's cashmere, there is enormous potential to improve that yield. Australian farmers deserve a pat on the back for their innovative approach and the fact that they are not frightened to venture into new areas.

The products of goat fibre are high-class in the textile area. The fibres are very specialist fibres and go into high-price and high-cost textile production. I hope and wish that at the same time as the industry develops in Australia the oncosting, the value added component of goat fibre, will be produced in this country rather than transferred overseas, as is still the case with our major animal fibre wool. We all know the story. The wool suit that I am wearing is made from Australian wool. The wool value is probably about 5 per cent of its total cost. The rest of the value is added by other countries before we bring the stuff back in again. I make a plea to Australian industry not to let this country become just a source of raw material. We should, as a nation, start taking advantage of the increase in goat fibre production and start doing the value added production in this country. By shipping off the raw wool and then having to buy back textiles we lose the value added component. We all know that this is one of the great problems in this country.

At present goat fibre research is funded from a variety of voluntary levies, gifts and ad hoc allocations. The mohair industry operates a voluntary research fund which has been largely financed by the mohair breeders of Australasia through members and voluntary contributions. The cashmere industry has deducted its own levy from cashmere sales for the purpose of cashmere research projects. In addition, the Australian Special Rural Research Fund has funded both industry-sponsored and other research which has benefited the goat fibre industry.

The national goat fibre workshop was convened in December 1988. It brought together goat fibre organisations to discuss key issues such as marketing, research and promotion. As a result of that this legislation is now before the House. There is widespread industry support and recognition. This sort of approach to an industry is very much a Government initiative-very much a part of the Government's response to what is occurring in our rural industries. Since March 1983 the Government has been implementing a consistent five-point plan. It has been maximising the competitiveness of the sector through general economic policy and maximising the returns to farmers through active trade policy and reforms of the marketing systems and institutions. The reform of these marketing institutions and systems has always been opposed by the Opposition. We have always been attacked when we have managed to reform industry groups.

Who on this side of the House can forget the anguished squeals, groans and moans and great outpourings of quasi-concern from the Opposition when there was a plan to restructure the dairy industry? I recall, as a member of the Prime Minister's country task force, wandering around the countryside with the shadow Minister who was telling farmers what was going to happen to them-what a disaster the Kerin plan was and how their marketing systems would be destroyed. Three or four years down the track, if someone says to a dairy farmer in Victoria, `The Kerin plan is going to be abolished', he will have a good fight on his hands. This is the tragedy of most of the changes that have occurred in rural sectors in marketing and systems.

Who can forget the shadow Minister's remarks in relation to wheat deregulation? He was going to resign and walk out of this place on the issue of wheat deregulation. Now he issues a policy on behalf of the Opposition which supports wheat deregulation. We on this side of the House get just a little confused as to where the National Party stands on any issue. TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to rise to support the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) in this consideration of the Goat Fibre Levy Amendment Bill. I indicate to the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) that I reiterate the support of the honourable member for Murray and the Opposition for the legislation currently before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Since pre-biblical times goats have been the subject of derision and scorn-good humoured derision and scorn though it has frequently been. Goats have been characterised as all that was stupid and unreasonable. I rise with some discomfort because I recognise that this measure of derision and scorn has also been aimed from time to time at those of us who practise the delicate art of politics. It is of some concern to me that the honourable member for McEwen failed to recognise that the Opposition supports the legislation. The Opposition has not been critical of the Government. The honourable member for Murray, in his comments about South Africa and the import of embryos, was referring to a matter that directly affects the goat industry and was therefore being relevant. The honourable member for McEwen had a great deal of audacity when he discussed justices of the peace, the dairy industry and the wheat industry after he had challenged the relevance of the remarks of the honourable member for Murray.

In my experience in this House the Opposition has, on the vast majority of occasions, supported the Government when legislation was fair and reasonable, sought after by industry and in the national interest. It does nothing for the image of parliamentarians for the cooperation that exists between the Opposition and the Government to be treated with nothing more than a characteristically supercilious outburst from the honourable member for McEwen.

The goat industry in Australia has played a key role in Australia's historic development, a role that has been frequently overlooked. I acknowledge that the honourable member for McEwen referred to the growth that we have seen in the cashmere industry and to the fact that in the mid-1800s the cashmere industry was seen as a possible industry in Australia and failed.

In fact, as a nation, our link with the goat industry goes back even further. Goats were amongst the animals brought out on the First Fleet. They were on the ships in the First Fleet so that the people would have a source of milk on the journey out. The early settlers who were involved in either railway construction or mining attempts used goats as a source of milk, cream, butter and meat to sustain themselves. So much a part of the Australian community and so much a part of the sustenance of the Australian community had the goat become that by the late nineteenth century the sport of goat racing had become popular among our early settlers.

I now move on to the remarks of the honourable member for McEwen, who indicated that a cashmere industry had been attempted in this country in 1832 but had failed, and that both cashmere and angora herds had been introduced into Australia and, because of the failure of the industry, many of them were set free. Some of them escaped and became a part of the herds of wild goats that were then emerging and were subsequently to become Australian feral goats and do some damage to our environment. It is not surprising that goats have damaged our environment. After all, they are a browsing animal. They are not very discriminating about the sort of feed that appeals to them. As a result of their presence in the environment, as we all know, there has been a breakdown in Australia's native shrubs. Rodents and marsupials that would also have been occupying that low grazing level of the Australian environment have been displaced by expanding goat herds.

It has to be acknowledged that, although goats played a role in making milk, meat and cheese available to our early settlers, those same feral goat herds that then took over the Australian environment have now become the foundation of the Australian goat industry. Firstly, the feral goat herds were the foundation for what was an expanding meat industry as people rounded up and slaughtered feral goats in order to supply an export meat market. Subsequently, these feral goat herds have become the foundation for a now expanding Australian cashmere and angora industry because they have become a part of the breeding stock for the Australian cashmere and angora industry. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, the angora industry exists to supply the mohair market. An expanding and popular mohair market has put a demand on Australian goat stocks, and so feral goats have been used to supplement those stocks.

Similarly, the cashmere pelt industry is seen as offering further opportunities for expansion, and the feral goat herds have provided a supplement to what was an almost non-existent cashmere industry in Australia. Over the last two decades we have seen a rapid increase in the numbers of goats being bred for mohair and cashmere production particularly. It is not surprising that, as a result of a fall in prices in both the mohair and the cashmere industries, over the last few years we have seen a fall in the number of goats being used for cashmere or mohair production.

I am fortunate enough to have in my electorate not only the President of the South Australian Goat Breeders Association but also the Senior Vice-President of the Australian Goat Breeders Association, Mr Dale Morphett. Mr Morphett, a farmer at Kadina who uses goats as a part of his total farm management, has indicated to me that, whereas in South Australia five years ago 300 people were involved in the goat industry, that number has fallen to 180 to 200 people who are members of the South Australian Goat Breeders Association. Australia-wide, people have moved out of the cashmere and angora industry as the price has fallen. In fact, Mr Morphett indicated to me that the Goat Breeders Association, which once boasted over 2,500 members throughout Australia, now has a membership closer to 2,200.

The glamour industry of cashmere pelts and mohair fibre has seen a fall in prices as Australian wool prices have risen. It seems that as wool prices go up cashmere and mohair prices tend to fall, and as goat fibre prices rise so wool prices tend to fall. The goat fibre industry goes through peaks and troughs which tend to characterise it. As I have indicated by the statistics I have presented to the House, these peaks and troughs tended to weed out those people who came into the industry hoping, if you will pardon the pun, Mr Deputy Speaker, simply for a quick buck.

As both the honourable member for Murray and the honourable member for McEwen have indicated, the industry agrees with the legislation before the House. In fact, the industry has shown a real desire to improve not only the quality of our breeding stock but also, consequently and subsequently, the quality of the fibre produced from those stock. The honourable member for Murray has quite rightly pointed to an additional step that the Government can contemplate in order to assist the industry, that is, the import of South African embryos to allow the industry to breed an even higher quality of both mohair and cashmere goats.

It is worth noting that under the current arrangements all mohair produced in Australia is sent to Bradford in England for processing. The levy arrangements currently before the House provide us with an opportunity to boost research funds for the goat industry. This boost in research funds and what might be confidently predicted as the consequent increase in the quality of mohair and angora pelts available could well lead not only to an increase in Australia's export earnings but also to the very real possibility of a value-added industry being created in Australia.

The Federal Government has indicated that it is prepared with this legislation, as with other rural legislation, to back the Australian goat industry dollar for dollar up to 0.5 per cent of its total production. This is consistent with the Government's approach to other primary industries. It is anticipated that the industry will of its own volition raise $150,000 as a result of this legislation-$150,000 for rural research which will be supplemented by about $50,000 from the Government.

In conclusion I want to make just two points. What has been seen as an environmentally hazardous industry, that is, the feral goat industry in Australia, need not in fact be environmentally hazardous at all. The honourable member for Murray has alluded to this. There is no escaping the damage that feral goats have done and are doing to the environment, but there is also no escaping the reality that market pressure has made it possible for farmers to hunt and slaughter these goats and so create an industry. The significant thing is that a controlled and managed goat industry plays a key role in ensuring that the Australian farming environment is even more sensitive than it was prior to the establishment of the goat industry. After all, as the honourable member for Murray has pointed out, goats can play a key role in allowing farmers to exercise pasture management that is not possible simply with sheep and cattle grazing. Goats are largely non-discriminate grazers and allow the farmers effectively to control weeds that would otherwise be difficult to control. So the goat industry need not be an environmentally insensitive industry. The feral goat industry may very likely be eliminated by the attraction of goat meat. A controlled goat industry would allow farmers to exercise even more sensitive pasture control than has been possible with the grazing of cattle and sheep.

I conclude by picking up the point made by the honourable member for Murray, and that is, Australian mohair breeders have formed their own company in a desperate effort to attract into Australia the genetic material they need from South Africa. Australian mohair breeders and goat breeders in total have shown that they belong to an industry committed to improving the genetic make-up of their industry and the quality of the pelts that will be harvested. They have shown that because they are prepared, through this legislation, to contribute up to three times the maximum being contributed to research and development by other primary industries in Australia. The goat industry has shown that it is committed to a more effective, more productive industry. If the Government is similarly committed it will do something about the importation of embryos from South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to speak in favour of the Goat Fibre Levy Bill and the Goat Fibre Levy Collection Bill which are being debated cognately. I compliment the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) on his remarks and also the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) who, in a bipartisan speech in this House, put forward some very rational and sound propositions in favour of agriculture.

SPEECH.PARA: I also pay tribute to my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) for the outstanding contribution that he has made on behalf of goat producers not only in his electorate but throughout Australia. We can recall that after repeated representations by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro on the industry's behalf a national goat fibre workshop was convened in December 1988. Another gentleman, Mr Bruce Turner, also had a part to play in the formulation of policy. He is no longer in Canberra. I thank him for his contribution and optimism regarding this industry which, as I have said, has untold potential.

The various grower organisations recognise the benefits of a coordinated research program involving all goat fibre organisations. The goat fibre organisation has three sectors-mohair, cashmere and cashgora. As previous speakers have said, over several years the industry has shown a willingness to involve itself in research activities. It is pleasing that in agriculture today almost everybody recognises the need for research as opposed to an earlier recognition by manufacturers alone.

However, the limited size of the industry has placed the level of research funding on a shaky footing. The industry requested the Federal Government to enact legislation to collect a statutory levy of 1.5 per cent on the gross value of sales of goat fibre, which is among the highest of any Australian agricultural industry. The maximum rate for this research will be 5 per cent of the value of fibre sales. The goat industry is export oriented and earnings are expected to be about $10m in 1989. The levy will take effect on 1 January 1990 and will be paid into the Australian Special Rural Research Fund. Research in all Australian industries is particularly important to ensure that we maintain our world-class reputation. Our primary producers are performing a formative role in showing industries the value of research, and that is great. However, by world standards Australia's research and development expenditure is quite low. All industries would do well to study and follow the example being set in the goat industry. It was interesting to note what the honourable member for Wakefield said regarding the processing of our products in England. He was right when he said that what we need to do is value-add those commodities in Australia. Looking at goat fibre earnings, which are currently small, and at the massive potential that exists if they were run on a parallel with wool, one does not have to be a genius to recognise the massive potential that exists there. Australian fashion designers can hold their own with anyone in the world. We produce the basic requirements in Australia. Through Bills such as those before us and research and development we can be better placed to value-add these products in Australia. I do not believe that a Cardin or St Laurent shirt is better than what we can make in Australia. If we put our mind to it, we can match the world. Honourable members on both sides of the House realise that that is what we have to do. While the legislation may not catch the newspaper headlines, because of the toing-and-froing that so often occurs in the House, it has more far-reaching ramifications than many people realise. On that basis, I commend the two Bills to the House and congratulate the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) for, once again, playing a great part in agriculture.
