DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 October 1989, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is designed to correct some deficiencies in two previous Bills. The first amendment relates to deficiencies in the Australian Industry Development Corporation Bill, which established the company called AIDC Ltd, to which I will refer later, and the second amendment is to the Bounty (Ships) Act, to expand the maximum size of bountiable vessels constructed or modified in Australia from 10,000 to 20,000 tonnes. Ship bounties are expected to peak at $33m in 1991 and thereafter to decline gradually as they are phased down to 10 per cent of eligible costs between 1991 and 1993 and 5 per cent of eligible costs between 1993 and 1995. When the bounties are phased out, the measure is unlikely to have much effect on decisions to build other unspecified vessels in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, there are minor amendments to the Designs Act and the Trade Marks Act and amendments to some administrative provisions in the Patents Act. The amendments will allow advances to administrative practice brought about by computerisation and will update penalties. The Opposition is not opposing the legislation, but those two areas strike me as being minor.

I direct my attention to the Australian Industry Development Corporation and the saga of the Australian Government's first sally into privatisation. I am particularly pleased to see in the House the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), who is a great supporter of privatisation! He has made it well known that he opposes privatisation at every turn, yet tonight he is supporting a Bill that will enable the first privatisation of a government enterprise to go on to the stock market. In the Government's first privatisation Bill it has managed, completely inaccurately, to draw the legislation at the bottom line. As a consequence of that, a prospectus has been issued for the float of AIDC Ltd which includes legislation that is wrong. Tonight the Government is amending the legislation to put into proper order its first effort at floating a company in Australia. That is quite an effort; not bad! One would have thought that the Government would have got it right at its first try, but it bombed out. Not only did it manage to bomb out on the legislation in the background to the float when the float took place but also the shares are now valued at less than what it placed them at. Firstly, the legislation was incorrect, and, secondly, when the shares were put out to the public, a few sales were made at a price above the offer price-now the value is well under that.

The question is: Who bought the shares? Does that ring a bell? The Japanese institutions bought them. The Government has done particularly well at its first effort at privatisation. I am pleased to see the Minister here; he is a great supporter of it all. He will be able to take those points down and use them the next time he talks about privatisation to members of the right wing faction in New South Wales. He might be able to tell them something about it; because they got it wrong. You, Mr Speaker, might pay some attention too, as you have a particular interest in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Ryan will not attempt to bring the Chair into the discussion.
—But I know your particular interest in financial matters, Mr Speaker; therefore I am following through.
—The honourable member for Ryan will get on with the debate.

—I draw your attention, Mr Speaker, to some points in what I find an absolutely fascinating operation. The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The reorganisation saw the bulk of the Corporation's business transferred to a new subsidiary company, AIDC Ltd.

This was a unique way of going about selling some government assets. The Australian Industry Development Corporation has been out there for a decade or so and has had an improved record in the past five years, but it wanted some money. One or two bright sparks in the Cabinet said, `The best way to get some money is to offer some of it to the public-not all of it, just a teeny-weeny bit of it, so we don't upset the left wing of the Labor Party. We will create a new subsidiary company and we will put certain assets into it.'. The Cabinet thought about what assets would be transferred and which ones would be kept in the Corporation. The Corporation has kept the ability to do all the fundraising or, in other words, the treasury operations. That is the term used here. That means, for the simple souls of the money market, that the Corporation will keep unto itself the power to raise money for the new AIDC Ltd and generally run its financial operations. The reason is that the Corporation had a government guarantee, but AIDC Ltd did not. That was a neat little attempt to put up to the public a company which had no advantages over any of the competitor merchant banks in the field, but the source of funds was coming from the Corporation which carried a government guarantee. That has been glossed over.

When the `non-transferable items' were left with the Corporation, it was apparently assumed that the costs of running those non-transferable assets would be passed to AIDC Ltd. That is what is said in the Minister's second reading speech, so I can only take it as truthful:

While the Corporation was to remain the contracting party to such agreements it was always intended that the actual benefits and costs associated with these non-transferable assets and liabilities would be transferred to the subsidiary.

In other words, the Corporation would continue to own the assets, but the cost of operation and the profits would be transferred to the new company. There was no agreement. If there was, it was not in the Act or the prospectus. That is another point down the drain. This is really very smart commercial work! Everyone will think that the first time the Labor Government got into privatisation it bungled it.
Let us look at what other little niceties are in it. The Minister said:

To reflect this position it was decided to treat these non-transferring assets and liabilities that were in substance part of the transferred business, as being assets and liabilities of the subsidiary for income tax purposes.

Someone rang the bell. It was forgotten that the profits and costs of an asset owned by A could not be transferred to corporation B if it did not own the asset and there was no agreement; that is fundamental. Any clown who has read the Income Tax Assessment Act would understand that; it is quite straightforward. In the rush to genius, those two things were bungled.
The Government did not stop there. In relation to the powers of the Chief Executive, I quote again from the Minister's speech:
Another aspect of the reorganisation was the transfer of the Corporation's staff to AIDC Ltd.
That is understandable. It goes on:

This necessitates the broadening of the Corporation's and the Chief Executive's delegation powers to include employees of the subsidiary. The establishment of AIDC Ltd also saw the Government examine the Corporation's use of the Commonwealth guarantee.'
Let us look at the Chief Executive's power. It is quite clear from page 33 of the prospectus which, quoting from the 1988 Act, states:

. . . empower the Chief Executive of the Corporation to determine which staff of the Corporation are to be transferred to the company. This determination was made on 30 June 1989 and took effect from 1 July 1989. All staff of the Corporation other than the Chief Executive are, by force of the 1988 Act, now deemed to be employed by the company-
that company being the AIDC Ltd-
on the same terms and conditions as they were employed by the Corporation.

Apparently the amendment is necessitated because in the drafting of this legislation the powers of the boss were not transferred. I can assume only that that is the case. I draw that same conclusion when I read the prospectus. Some detail is given about the guarantee. The Minister, in his second reading speech, attempted to wash his hands of the problems with the guarantee. He said:

To remove the guarantee any earlier would have created an unacceptable degree of uncertainty not only for lenders to and other parties involved with the Corporation but also for the subsidiary as it tries to establish itself in the marketplace.
In other words, that was quite clearly an attempt to pass on to the subsidiary which was floated a Crown guarantee on debt by way of subterfuge.

I view these matters with concern. The prospectus is very formidable, very substantial, and it is well put together. The professional people who were associated with its production, namely, the underwriters and advisers, have quite impeccable reputations. Were's is a very respected house in Australia and so are the other associated parties.

I am astonished that a prospectus with that backing can be offered to the public, be accepted and floated and that legislation then comes back to Parliament to amend the original legislation to make the prospectus valid. Those shares, I remind the House, have been on the market for some time. On its first time around the track the Government put out a prospectus that was invalid in law. If the Liberal Party were in government, the AIDC would be sold in total. There would be no mucking around and no need for subsidiary companies. The Government made a mess of the original float when it offered the shares at $2 on a prospectus the legislation for which subsequently had to be amended. TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to listen to the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), although I caught only the end of his remarks. SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member went on to bring out the old chestnuts. He spoke of the coalition parties in their policies and Economic Action Plan somehow targeting the poor. That is politics, I suppose, but it brings no credit to either gentleman or to anyone else from either side of the political fence. I will make some remarks about the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) and Senator Button. I acknowledge the comments of the honourable member for Chifley along these lines.

This omnibus Bill, the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), seeks to amend a range of legislation in the industry, technology and commerce portfolio. It considers changes to the AIDC, the Bounty (Ships) Act and legislation dealing with designs, patents and trademarks. The legislation gives the House an opportunity to consider the limited scope of the formerly much heralded achievements of industry policy under the Hawke Labor Government. Industry policy of this Government has been a mirage designed to cover up the glaring omissions and complete inability of the Government to handle the deep problems faced by Australian industry. Indeed, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has acknowledged his disappointment with the results of Labor Government policy. The Minister said that! The Minister said that he was unsure where Government policy could go from here.

The truth is that industry policy has undergone significant changes since the early days of this Labor Government. The early days of this Government saw an industry policy based on the provisions of the first version of the now failed accord. It promoted sectoral industry plans determined by close consultation between representatives of business, representatives of employees, and the Government. One of the problems of this approach was that, although it involved representatives, it did not for those who were directly involved in businesses. There was an isolated unreality about the whole procedure. The idea was that the sector plans would set targets and plan development of industry along with the gradual reduction in protection. The representatives had the role of protecting employment and increasing the productivity of industry.

The models of the sectoral industry plans were the steel industry plan, the car industry plan and the textiles, clothing and footwear industry plan. The steel industry plan included significant Government support-by that I mean taxpayers' and consumers' money. As a consequence, employment in the steel industry has been reduced but efficiency has been held back by other labour market rigidities and the problems of the union-dominated coal industry. Earlier in the year, significant supply problems at Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd caused considerable difficulty for local manufacturers and users of steel products. The levels of protection in the steel industry are still high.

The much heralded car plan has been even less successful. It was designed to reduce the number of local manufacturers to three and reduce the number of car models available to consumers. It certainly has done that, but whether in the process it has created more competition is a lot less clear. In its 1986-87 annual report, the Industries Assistance Commission presented a damning critique of the car plan which suggested that it had done little more than reduce choice to consumers while reducing protection at such a slow rate that there would be little increase in efficiency and, therefore, little improvement in the price of cars to consumers or cars for potential export. Similar criticisms could be made of the textiles, clothing and footwear plan. It has produced an initial increase in protection before very slow reductions of protection to the industry are introduced.

At the end of six years of Labor rule, we still have very heavily protected industries in these areas. The alternative to this sectoral approach to reducing protection would have been across the board reductions in protection to all industries. The sectoral approach has allowed vested interests in particular industries to concentrate their efforts against government attempts to reduce protection to those industries. It has not worked. Through detailed plans, it has reduced the flexibility and adaptability of industry to changing circumstances. It has helped to maintain labour market problems, and allowed the Government to ignore the wider economic problems facing all industry, such as the centralised wage fixing system, a tax system which encourages debt over savings, the mess on the waterfront and the inflationary policies which it has pursued.

We no longer hear of new sectoral industry plans from the Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce. He was badly burnt by the failure of the car plan. What has replaced that failed plan is ad hoc measures to suit the political needs of the Government and the demands, of course, of the ever present Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). As a consequence, the Government will spend $60m to support the old Kodak plant in the electorate of Wills. However, it cannot find the money to support the Sarich engine project elsewhere. I am not saying that either project should be supported, but the Government cannot maintain any shred of credibility in terms of its industry policy when it decides that Kodak is a winning bet for Government support when Sarich is not.

Its corporate policies of meetings with big unions, big business and big government have undermined the role of the Parliament and have failed to deliver policy for all Australians. The Government has become dependent on pandering to vested interests such as the trade union movement, the environmental movement, the welfare lobby, and other groups, always to the detriment of the more general interests of the majority of Australians. With industry policy, such an approach is particularly damaging. It represents a burden on taxpayers and consumers.

The Minister, in this legislation and in his administration of the portfolio, gives no indication of an alternative to the industry policy which he has tried and which has failed. The Bill contains amendments to the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act which rectified deficiencies in the earlier legislation which further facilitated the corporatisation of the AIDC. The AIDC operates almost entirely in competition with the private sector in the highly competitive finance industry. The Corporation is ultimately guaranteed by the Federal Government, giving it access to reduced interest rates and a competitive advantage over private sector firms.

The AIDC was formed, like the Western Australia Development Corporation (WADC), the Victorian Economic Development Corporation (VEDC) and equivalent bodies in other States, to promote local industry through the provision of loans and assistance to firms which might have difficulty getting finance through normal commercial channels. In the case of the WADC and the VEDC this has certainly been the case. The WADC, from my own State, made almost no profit from normal commercial trading arrangements, and used its privileged access to Government to prop up its balance sheet. The VEDC lost millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds on fruitless subsidies for firms which failed to meet the most basic financial criteria that are applied by professional lending institutions.

The AIDC is not by any means in the league of its State-based equivalents, in terms of incompetence. The indications are that it is a profitable operation on its own merits, although not particularly so. The question then is: Why should the Federal Government own a merchant bank? It is not possible to argue that Australia has such poorly developed financial markets that the budding entrepreneur cannot find support for new projects. Indeed, honourable members opposite are often heard criticising the banks for too readily lending money to those whom they brand as speculators. There is presently a real problem finding equity investors for many small companies, but that has more to do with the economic mess created by this Government than a problem which the AIDC can rectify.

The Government should privatise the AIDC. Privatisation will remove the competitive advantage which the AIDC has through government guarantees, and also remove the taxpayers' liability, both real and potential, for the AIDC. It will increase the efficiency of the services delivered by the AIDC and give the Corporation the independence to expand and develop its business as it sees fit. It will provide the Commonwealth with funds to help pay off some of the huge foreign debt which its policies have engendered. It will remove the impossible dilemmas facing statutory authorities which have a responsibility to be accountable to the Parliament, yet operate in a very different commercial environment which demands a degree of confidentiality.

The AIDC is perhaps the best case of a Government-owned enterprise which should be privatised. It already competes in an open market. None of the usual reasons for government involvement in industry exists to justify the continued government ownership of the AIDC. Indeed, the Government, through the Commonwealth Bank's activities, is often in competition with the Government itself through the AIDC. How preposterous! The truth of the Government's difficulties with privatisation is that some senior Ministers know it to be essential, but the back bench, a whole murder of crows, and the trade union movement will not permit the privatisation which would allow real competition and threaten the monopoly position of government services. In particular, the Commonwealth Bank and the AIDC need access to private sector funds to maintain their capital base and their market shares.

Honourable members opposite have spent a lot of effort trying to dream up schemes to maintain government control of these government-owned business enterprises while gaining access to private funds. However, none of these schemes address the fundamental problem which is government ownership. As long as the Government owns a business, it cannot withdraw its capital and it cannot let that business fail. It is this basic fact that makes corporatisation a tried and failed concept. Corporatisation is at best a desirable step on the path to full privatisation of a government-owned business. It can serve to increase the competitiveness of the business when it is privatised and, therefore, to maximise the price received for privatisation by the Commonwealth. It is very valuable. Sure, it can be built up to get the best price for the benefit of taxpayers generally. In the coalition's case that benefit can be applied to reduce some of that massive overseas debt which we now do not enjoy.

This Bill fails, by omission, to address any of the grave problems facing Australian industry and government-owned businesses. Eventually, these deficiencies will be corrected, but it is increasingly likely that it will not be this Government which introduces those changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) deals with a number of issues which relate to industry policy. These issues in themselves are not of great intrinsic importance; they are largely machinery matters that are consequential from earlier substantive decisions that have been taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to make a number of specific comments about the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC), to which a number of the amendments refer. In the course of doing that, I would like to make some comment on the contribution of the preceding speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). He posed the question why it was that the Commonwealth was owning what was in effect a merchant bank-what was the justification for government ownership of what is effectively a merchant bank? That is a reasonable question to ask in the context of quite a debate within the Australian Labor Party about the future of the AIDC. I do not think it is any great secret that the proposal to restructure the AIDC in the way it is being done-that is, by transferring the great bulk of its assets to a newly created subsidy organisation and then floating off up to 30 per cent of that to the private sector-was quite a controversial decision in the context of the overall privatisation debate.

In order to have a sensible debate about that, it is necessary to address some broader issues relating to the whole thrust of industry policy as it is evolving. The honourable member for Curtin expressed opposition to the Government's broad approach to industry policy, its emphasis on sectoral plans and so forth. He talked about the steel industry plan and the motor industry plan and pointed to what he claimed were deficiencies in the outcomes from those plans. Nobody pretends that everything has been absolutely rosy. Certainly, if the question were asked whether those industries would have been better off with or without the sectoral plans that have been implemented, I do not think there is much doubt that the answer would be that we have come out with more competition and viability in the long term industry sectors as a result of the application of the Government's plans than would have been the case in their absence.

I would suggest that the clearest example of that is the steel industry plan. In 1982 it was becoming widely accepted that there was no future for the steel industry in Australia. In fact, there was a general mood of pessimism pervading the steel industry in particular. What we have seen as a result of the application of the steel industry plan is a massive program of investment which exceeded the targets that were set out in the original steel industry plan. As a consequence, we have ended up with a major modernisation of plant and equipment and the development of an industry which is actually capable of sustaining itself and of competing on world markets and which has enjoyed a considerable degree of success in establishing a number of overseas markets for specialised products, particularly coated steels.

That was the scenario confronting that industry in 1982. There is simply no comparison with what it now faces. To suggest that that sectoral plan has not been highly successful is absurd. That is not to say that there are not problems and that there is not room for considerable further improvement. But again I go back to the issue of whether that sector would have been better with or without the industry plan. I do not think there is any serious doubt about that. One could make comments about the other plans, but I do not intend to take much time talking about that in the context of this speech.

I prefer to talk about the AIDC's role and return to the issue of why there should be a government owned merchant bank. It seems to me that the key issue here is the time horizons of those in Australia who are responsible for controlling or who have the capacity to control major flows of investment funds. I do not think there is a great deal of dispute amongst those who comment on Australian industry and economic policy that the relatively short time horizons of Australia's capital markets represent a major problem in terms of the long term restructuring of Australian industry. I have spoken to a whole variety of people about that, including senior figures in the major institutions which control some of the large pools of investment funds. There is not a huge amount of argument from those quarters that Australian industry and those who make the major investment decisions about where funds are going to go in Australia have time horizons which are too short. That is a strong contrast with those countries which have developed economically successfully-for example, Japan, whose financial systems and industrial structures reward long term thinking and long term concentration on development of new products, new processes and maximising market share rather than short term profitability.

I think there would be wide agreement that a shift in culture in Australia in that direction is desirable. There is also fairly wide agreement that there is a degree of market failure in the Australian capital market in its tendency to undervalue relatively long term and risky types of investment. If one accepts that there is a degree of market failure there, then there is an issue of how that might be addressed. The AIDC, as a government owned merchant bank, in effect, is an institution which is capable to some extent of addressing that problem. One could argue that it needs to be rather more substantial than it is and that its ability to influence the development of Australian industry structure is inherently rather slight because of its current size. I think that is probably a true proposition.

I suppose that one of the criticisms I would make of governments of all persuasions in recent years is the failure to adequately support the capital base of AIDC. That an organisation such as the AIDC, whose funding should be the result of long term planning and long term decisions, is constantly severely squeezed as a result of relatively short term macro-economic concerns is a major problem in the way that our budgetary processes operate and in the way we lump together expenditures of a capital and recurrent nature which, in economic terms, are very different and have quite distinct consequences. As a result of that, a number of government business enterprises, including the AIDC, I would suggest, have not been adequately supported in terms of needed injections to their capital base.

Of course, how to strengthen the AIDC's capital base lies at the heart of the proposals to restructure the AIDC. The argument has been that, under current macro-economic circumstances, it is inappropriate for governments, directly from Budget outlays, to fund the necessary capital injections for the AIDC. The argument is that, if the AIDC is to be able to adequately fulfil its industry restructure role and adequately get involved in relatively risky types of equity investments, it needs a stronger gearing ratio than it now has and that involves major injections of new capital. If those injections of new capital are to come from Budget outlays, which it is said is unfeasible under current economic circumstances, then they have to be funded by selling equity to the private sector.

This restructuring plan is an attempt to do that without cutting across the grain of the Labor Party's objection to privatisation by the establishment of a subsidiary organisation: maintain the parent company in 100 per cent government ownership, create a subsidiary, transfer just about all the assets of the AIDC to that subsidiary, and then float off 30 per cent of that. In that way, one maintains 100 per cent government ownership with the parent organisation, but a subsidiary is created which is capable of raising funds from the private sector. That is the argument.

One fundamental contention in terms of budgetary accounting conventions is that it makes no sense to say, on the one hand, that it is okay and perfectly responsible economically to float off a 30 per cent equity, yet on the other hand to say that to float off an equivalent amount in additional government borrowings or bonds over and above what would have otherwise been required is somehow irresponsible. There is absolutely no economic sense in that.

Interestingly enough, that point has been conceded in the last few days in the debate about the Opposition's economic package, a significant part of which it seeks to fund by sales of assets. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has correctly pointed out, to fund any part of the Opposition's package by selling assets or equity in government enterprises is, in economic terms, no different from selling an equivalent amount of government bonds. The point that the Treasurer has made is equally applicable in this case. I do not think that the fundamental rationale for that type of restructuring basically holds water.

One must ask: What is the consequence of selling equity to the private sector? There is a view that by selling equity to the private sector the AIDC will become more responsive to market forces. In that sense it will become in its behaviour more like a conventional merchant bank. To me, there is a real argument about whether that is a good thing. In my view the case for retaining the AIDC in public ownership is precisely in order to have an institution which will behave other than as a conventional merchant bank. As I outlined earlier, one of the major economic problems we face in Australia is the fact that our capital markets have short time horizons, that the markets, left to themselves, will not put adequate levels of investment into those industries which are essential to Australia's economic restructuring.

The AIDC, despite whatever criticisms have been made of it, has already played an important role in that restructuring process. One could refer to its role in the heavy engineering plan and its envisaged role in the textile, clothing and footwear plan as facilitating that process of structural change in specific industry sectors. I believe there is a need for such an institution, and a need for such an institution to be, to a considerable extent, insulated from the short term pressures of the market. I would like to express very strongly my view that the AIDC needs to be retained as an essentially government owned enterprise. The arguments for privatisation put forward by the Opposition do not hold water. There is a need for an institution of this type which will be a relatively flexible instrument for government intervention-so that the government can take out equity, and provide various forms of intervention in the economy. Without that, structural change does not have much prospect of success.

In this context the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its Australia Reconstructed document actually envisages a much larger role for the AIDC in the longer term. It put forward a proposal for a national development fund which seeks to channel 20 per cent of the future earnings of superannuation funds and to make them available to a certain extent for the purpose of industry development and industry policy. In putting forward that proposal it envisaged a significant role for the AIDC in terms of managing and operating that national development fund. That is a proposal which has not been taken up by the Government or by any party as yet, but I think that over the longer term there is an increasing recognition of whether the sort of role that the superannuation funds are playing is adequate in facilitating the process of economic restructuring. A huge amount of funds will accumulate in those superannuation funds over the next few decades. That, to me, is one of the really crucial issues of economic policy that we face at the moment. I think there will be a lot more concern about and a lot more interest in giving thought to how those superannuation funds are to be utilised.

There is a need for an institution like the AIDC, perhaps with a changed structure, but there needs to be some organisation which is capable of directing and managing those funds in the interests of industry development purposes. SPEECH.PARA: There has been some discussion about the implications of changing the upper limit applied to bountiable ships under the Bounty (Ships) Act 1989. SPEECH.PARA: This legislation really represents a lack of comprehension by the Government of what it needs to address in terms of appropriate policies to deal with the problems of Australia at this time. I do not think any of us should forget for a minute that this very day this country is facing one of the most fundamental economic crises of its history. On only two other occasions in Australia's history has it faced such dire economic circumstances. That was in the 1890s and in the 1930s, when every other country faced similar circumstances. The big difference between the circumstances of the 1890s and the 1930s and the circumstances of today is that in the 1890s and the 1930s the world, not just Australia, was faced with a very serious depression. In 1989 the world is not confronted with a fundamental recession. We are living through a period of very strong global economic growth. We are living through a period of very strong economic activity which is ensuring, for example, that Australian commodity prices remain at a relatively buoyant level. That was not the case in the 1980s, nor was it the case in the 1930s.

In those circumstances, the Government basically offers a strategy that is underlined in this legislation-a reduction in funding for the States-and a strategy of high interest rates. The Government offers absolutely nothing else at all. The interesting thing about that approach is that it has already been shown not to work. The Government's high interest rate strategy, a strategy that has been tried all over the world from time to time, is simply not working. One of the two reasons why it is not working is that high interest rates inflate the value of the Australian dollar beyond a level which would normally be its market value.

If the Government wants to inflate the Australian dollar beyond its normal level, one of the consequences of that is to make imports cheaper and exports more expensive than would naturally be the case. The consequences are clearly not positive ones for our balance of payments. That is the reason why, after 18 months of a high interest rate strategy, our balance of payments situation has not improved, as is continually being predicted by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), but has progressively deteriorated. Although today's figures may be marginally better than those for the previous month-and, seasonally adjusted, the improvement is extremely slight-the simple fact is that the balance of payments situation for September is the worst in the history of Australia. So this is not a strategy that has proved to be enormously successful. In the context of this legislation, this reduction in States grants likewise has not been a successful contribution to our economic strategy. It has not been adequate.

The other point that one has to make about interest rates is that if a strategy such as reducing States grants and having high interest rates and no other is pursued, high interest rates will militate against domestic investment. In other words, they will militate against the capacity of Australian businesses, in particular, small businesses that have no capacity to borrow money in Japan, West Germany or the United States, where interest rates may be substantially lower. They have to borrow money in Australia, and they are borrowing money at rates ranging between 19 and 23 per cent. If businesses are doing that, they clearly do not have the capacity to invest in productive activity as they might be able to do if interest rates were substantially lower than they are currently.

As I have pointed out, the strategy of just maintaining high interest rates and doing what this legislation does-that is, simply reducing the allocation of funds to the States whilst on the other hand increasing Commonwealth spending in areas of Commonwealth programs-is a flimsy one which ultimately is not working.

We made that perfectly clear in the Economic Action Plan released a couple of weeks ago by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). We make no apology for the fact that in that plan the Leader of the Opposition announced on behalf of, and with enormous support from, all of us on this side of the House that there would be a reduction in allocations to the States of some $300m. Perhaps one of the ways in which the States could achieve greater efficiencies is exactly the way in which we on this side of the House propose greater efficiencies at the Commonwealth level-through the practice of contracting out a large amount of work that is currently done by the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth Public Service.

I have referred to the New South Wales Government. That Government has already shown that the practice of contracting out can lead to enormous savings and efficiencies. I suspect that if other governments, such as the Western Australian Government, which has its own problems, the Victorian Government, which has enormous problems, and the South Australian Government, which not only faces its own internal problems but also will have great problems with the people very soon, were prepared to abandon their ideological commitment to nationalisation and public enterprise, they would soon realise that they would be able to achieve enormous savings through the practice of contracting out.

He makes the argument that just about everything in South Australia would close down and the world, at least so far as South Australia is concerned, would come to an end.

The experience of New South Wales is that the practice of contracting out and a greater involvement of the private sector in the provision of services to the community will in fact achieve enormous savings, and all the South Australian Government is being asked to save here is something which, if one were to take a percentage figure, is in the vicinity of $20m. That is not the figure, by the way, that Mr Bannon chooses to use; he chooses to use a grossly exaggerated figure, no doubt in order to try to achieve some sort of emotive reaction that will help him with the electoral problems which will face him, I think I am right in saying, on 9 December when we will see whether that is the consequence.

The point is a very important one. It is that in Australia, where we have various levels of government-the Commonwealth Government, the State governments and local government-we need to ensure that, within that federal system, proper efficiencies are achieved. Our federal system is a system that can work extremely well and extremely efficiently, but it will only work well and it will only work efficiently if there is proper cooperation and there is a determination to avoid duplication by the Commonwealth and the States and if, at each level of government-and I include local government in this-as much private sector involvement is obtained as is humanly possibly.

Obviously there will always be a role for the public sector. There will always be a role for government at the local government, the State government and the Commonwealth government level. But the fact is that the more private sector involvement that can be achieved and the more competitive the provision of services that can be achieved, the more will be the saving to the ordinary members of the community and the taxpayers.
